Study area 
The study was in the central highlands of Vietnam, one of the world’s most important robusta coffee producing areas.

55.text_preview:
To investigate 
the impact of climate on robusta coffee beans we used data from Vietnamese farmers.

value of robusta co

Lam Dong, Dak Lak, Dak Nong, Gia Lai, and Kon Tum. These areas account for

62.text_preview:
Over the study period from 2012 to 2016 mean annual minimum and maximum temperatures in the region were 21.8 ◦C and 
29.9 ◦C respectively, while mean total annual rainfall was 2128 mm (NCHMF, 2018).

63.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
63.text_preview:
The coffee growing season in Lam Dong runs 
from January to September.

64.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
64.text_preview: Flowering runs from approximately January to February.

65.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
65.text_preview:
The early growing season (including cherry 
development) from March to June, while the late growing season (including cherry maturation) from July to September.

66.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
66.text_preview:
Harvest is 
from late October to December.

67.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
67.text_preview: Rainfall in the Central Highlands is usually concentrated around the summer monsoon (May-October).

68.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
68.text_preview:
However, the rainy season 
onset data (RSOD) is primarily driven by El Ni˜no-Southern Oscillation (ENSO), which is responsible for substantial variation between

69.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
69.text_preview:
The RSOD generally starts later in El Ni˜no years and earlier during a La Ni˜na (Pham- 
Thanh et al., 2020).

70.text_preview:

years and will continue to do so in future (Schmidt-Thome et al., 2015; Pham-Thanh et

71.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
71.text_preview:
In accordance with other regions of 
SE-Asia, temperatures have increased over Vietnam and are projected to increase further under future climate scenarios (Schmidt- 
Thome et al., 2015).

73.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
73.text_preview:
Robusta coffee cultivation practices 
Coffee in the study area is cultivated under open sun, with some inter-cropping of fruit and timber trees.

74.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
74.text_preview:
Overall, farms ranged from 
0.2 to 6.0 ha in size and were located between 694 and 905 masl.

75.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
75.text_preview:
In the study region, bean yield varied between 2.8 and 6.8 ton−1 ha, 
and average yield recorded at 3.8 ton−1 ha.

76.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
76.text_preview:
Plants are irrigated during the dry season (January – April) to synchronize flowering and 
fruit setting, and to protect the crop from droughts and boost production (Byrareddy et al., 2020).

77.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
77.text_preview:
The major fertilizer types applied are 
blended NPK, urea, superphosphate and potassium chloride) in addition to compost and lime and is applied around four times in year 
(Byrareddy et al., 2019).

78.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
78.text_preview:
The major pest and disease affecting the crop are respectively mealybugs (Hemiptera: Pseudococcidae) and 
anthracnose (Colletotrichum spp.).

79.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
79.text_preview: Farmers rely on chemical control as the main pest and disease management strategy.

80.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
80.text_preview:
The harvest is 
carried out manually by hand picking in 2–3 rounds, farmers collect the coffee cherries and dry them under open sun prior to pro­
cessing.

81.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
81.text_preview:
The surveyed farmers reported, drying and hulling of cherries takes about 8 to 10 sunshine days, and if it rains during this 
period they protect it by using plastic sheets.

90.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
90.text_preview: Coffee bean size was assessed based on ISO 4150 (Size analysis — Manual and machine sieving).

91.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
91.text_preview:
This involved transferring a 100 g 
test portion into a series of sieves of descending screen sizes (16 (largest) to 12 (smallest)).

92.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
92.text_preview:
Coffee beans were then agitated on sieves by 
hand for 3 min so that beans covered the whole perforated surface.

93.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
93.text_preview:
After this the sieves were tapped once on a firm surface so that any 
beans loosely retained in the holes fell into the next sieve size.

94.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
94.text_preview:
The amount of coffee retained on each sieve and in the receiver was then 
weighed and transformed to a percentage (ISO, 2011).

95.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
95.text_preview:
Bean defects were calculated as in ISO 10,470 (Green coffee — Defect reference 
chart).

96.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
96.text_preview:
Sample size for defect counts was based on a representative sample of 300 g. The percentage of total defect beans, which 
included those with foreign matter (stones, sticks and husk), black, broken an

Analyses 
The probability of certain coffee bean characteristics occurring was quantified using hierarchical models (also referred to as mixed- 
effect or multi-level models), which included climate v

107.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
107.text_preview: from annual repeat measurements at a particular site).

108.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
108.text_preview:
Traditional non-hierarchal linear regression 
models do not account for repeat measures or non-independence in observations.

109.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
109.text_preview:
For example, bean characteristic observations at a 
site, or within particular years, may be more similar (e.g.

110.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
110.text_preview:
higher on average if soils and management techniques are better) relative to 
other sites or during different years.

111.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
111.text_preview:
To account for this, hierarchical modelling allows for the intercept (or baseline) in the model to 
vary amongst the same sites and years.

112.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf
112.text_preview:
Hierarchical statistical models efficiently account for the influence of these grouping factors (e. 
g. site and year) and eliminate many problems associated with spatial and temporal autocorrelation,

113.filename: (2021) Temperature and rainfall impacts on robusta coffee.pdf

hierarchical models allow for the intercept to vary, this enabled us to quantify the effect of rainfall and temperature on coffee bean 
characteristi

management practices) and the non-independence of coffee bean 
data at each site.

544.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
544.text_preview:
Chapter 4
Plant nutrition & fertiliser management
Nutrients are recycled within the environment.

545.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
545.text_preview:
A 'closed' environment such as a rainforest,
recycles its own nutrients and is more or less self-sufficient.

546.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
546.text_preview:
However, where plants are grown
in a commercial situation, it is necessary to replenish the nutrients that are removed from the
system.

547.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
547.text_preview:
Without additional nutrients in some form of fertiliser, coffee yields will remain very low
as nutrients are removed with the coffee beans.

548.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
548.text_preview:
Unshaded plants of dwarf, high-yielding
varieties such as Catimor, will quickly develop dieback and die if adequate nutrients and water
are not added to the soil.

549.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
549.text_preview:
Plants with mild to moderate dieback will recover with timely good
fertilising, watering and weed management.

550.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
550.text_preview:
In India, it was found that for every 6,000 kg of ripe coffee cherry (1 tonne of green bean)
removed from the plants, approximately 40 kg nitrogen (N), 2.2 kg phosphorus (P) and 53 kg
potassium (K) mu

551.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
551.text_preview: There are 16 natural elements (nutrients), that are essential for plant growth (see table below).

552.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
552.text_preview:
Three elements (carbon, hydrogen and oxygen) make up 94% of the plant tissues and are
obtained from air and water.

553.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
553.text_preview:
The other 13 elements are obtained from the soil and are divided
into two broad categories - 'macro' and 'micro'.

554.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
554.text_preview:
These terms do not refer to the importance of
the elements; macronutrients are required in greater amounts than micronutrients for normal
plant growth.

555.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
555.text_preview:
Essential minerals and their role in the coffee plant
Mineral/
Chemical
Main requirement/use by the plant

556.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
556.text_preview:
To keep
costs down, and if plantings are of the same
age and appearance, three samples per two
to four hectare block will be adequate,
provided the three samples are composites
from the 20 sites sampl

557.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
557.text_preview: To help determine the best nutrition practices, soil and leaf analyses are recommended.

558.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
558.text_preview:
While
Lao currently does not have access to these services, in nearby Thailand the Mae Jo
University in Chiang Mai and Department of Land Development (DLD) can offer fee-for-service
analyses.

559.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
559.text_preview:
The FAO project used Mae Jo University for the soil and leaf analysis survey of
Arabica coffee farms in the Bolovens in 2005.

560.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
560.text_preview:
In order to standardize procedures between farms, years and personnel involved, the following
practices are suggested for soil and leaf analysis.

561.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

562.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
562.text_preview:
Remove surface litter and old fertiliser etc., from area to be sampled but do not
remove soil.

563.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
563.text_preview:
Take samples to a depth of 150 mm
Remove surface litter (leaves, etc.)

564.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

565.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

566.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
566.text_preview: Take samples to a depth of 150 mm with soil auger or spade.

567.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
567.text_preview: Place soil in a CLEAN bucket.

568.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
568.text_preview: Sample from a minimum of 20 sites across a block of two to four hectares.

569.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
569.text_preview:
Thoroughly mix each soil sample collected and then sub-sample to reduce volume for
sample bags.

570.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
570.text_preview: Properly label all samples and laboratory sheets.

571.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
571.text_preview: Clean the auger or spade after sampling each of the sites.

572.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
572.text_preview:
DO NOT sample after fertilizer application. Scrape away any fertilizer/lime residue from
previous applications before taking a sample.

573.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
573.text_preview: Do not sample next to shade trees.

574.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
574.text_preview:
Areas of different tree size, age, soil types, fertilizer or other major differences should be
treated as separate samples.

575.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
575.text_preview: Samples need to be dried before sending for analysis.

576.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
576.text_preview:
If laboratory ovens are
unavailable, spread out each sample on a paper bag or plain paper and dry slowly on
raised benches under shade and protected from rain.

577.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
577.text_preview:
Samples are usually air dry in four
to five days.

578.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
578.text_preview: If possible, soil samples should be taken once per year before flowering.

579.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
579.text_preview:
Leaf sampling
The objective of leaf sampling is to get an
AVERAGE (representative sample) of trees,
not the best or the worst.

580.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
580.text_preview:
The 40 trees per
hectare samples can be bulked and three
composite samples made to reduce analysis
costs.

581.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
581.text_preview:
A minimum of 100 leaves is needed for
each composite sample.

582.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

583.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
583.text_preview:
Leaf sampling
Sample the third or fourth pair of leaves from the tip of an actively growing branch.

584.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
584.text_preview:
Do
not count new leaves if they are not fully expanded (Figure 24).

585.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
585.text_preview: Sample at the same time/growth stage each year, before flowering.

586.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
586.text_preview: Sample a minimum of 40 trees per block across a block size of two to four hectares.

587.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

588.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

589.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
589.text_preview:
Do not sample obviously sick, excessively healthy or
odd/unusual coffee trees.

590.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
590.text_preview: Sample in the morning where possible when leaves are the most turgid (full of water).

591.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

592.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
592.text_preview:
Do not smoke while sampling and make sure hands are free of
fertilizer, soil etc.

593.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
593.text_preview: Do not sample when leaves are wet as the paper sample bags will break!

594.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
594.text_preview: Do not sample after any application of foliar fertilizer sprays.

595.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
595.text_preview:
Areas of different tree size, age, soil types, fertilizer or other major differences should be
treated as separate samples.

596.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
596.text_preview: Properly label all samples and laboratory sheets.

597.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
597.text_preview: Samples are to be stored in paper (not plastic) bags.

598.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
598.text_preview:
Keep leaves cool but do not
freeze!

599.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
599.text_preview: Samples need to be dried if they are not sent for analysis within one to two days.

600.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
600.text_preview:
This is
normally done at the laboratory at 60 to 65°C until dry and brittle.

601.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
601.text_preview: Pre-flowering is preferred sampling time if only one sample is taken each year.

602.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
602.text_preview:
More frequent
sampling (every four months) is highly desirable for large plantations, especially if nutritional
problems occur.

603.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
603.text_preview:
A soil and leaf sampling survey on 15 properties has recently been conducted on the Bolovens
Plateaux; results were not available at the time of publication.

604.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
604.text_preview:
Optimum leaf and soil nutrient levels

Once the soil and leaf samples have been taken, it is important to analyse the results and
compare them to levels that have been determined as optimum in coffee

605.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
605.text_preview:
Optimum leaf nutrient levels
Nutrient
Optimum range
Nutrient
Optimum range
N (Nitrogen)
2.5 - 3.0% Na (Sodium)
< 0.05%
P (Phosphorus)
0.15 - 0.2% Cu (Copper)
16 - 20 mg/kg
K (Potassium)
2.1 - 2.6% Zn

606.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
606.text_preview:
Fertiliser programme
Fresh manure or non-composted pulp should
never be used as they can burn the plants
and tie up nitrogen in the soil during break-
down.

607.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
607.text_preview:
They also are a source of Orchratoxin
A (OTA) moulds.

608.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
608.text_preview:
Coffee soils in Lao PDR are low in a number of essential plant nutrients; therefore these must
be supplied to promote high yielding, high quality coffee.

609.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
609.text_preview:
Manure, bio-fertiliser, cover crops,
compost, legume tree leaves and shoots and chemical fertilisers all supply nutrients.

610.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
610.text_preview: Manure and compost such as coffee pulp and husks have a low nutrient content.

611.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
611.text_preview:
When utilised
as a source of nutrients, they must be used in large quantities to supply sufficient nutrients for
coffee plants.

612.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
612.text_preview: Manure and compost help improve soil structure and organic matter.

613.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
613.text_preview:
Chemical fertilisers are higher in nutrient content than organic fertilisers and are a more
effective method of applying nutrients.

614.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
614.text_preview:
For optimal results, it is best to apply a combination of
manure and compost and chemical fertilisers.

615.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
615.text_preview:
At present, there has been little or no soil and leaf analysis services available for Lao coffee
growers.

616.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
616.text_preview:
When such services are available, a detailed coffee fertiliser programme can be
devised.

617.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
617.text_preview: Meanwhile the following fertiliser programme is suggested for Arabica coffee in Lao.

618.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
618.text_preview:
Year
Time
Application
Year 1
(Up to 12 months in the field)
Before rains finish
September
30 g/tree of NPK 15-15-15
Year 2
April/May (with first rains)
30 g/tree of NPK 15-15-15
July
30 g/tree of NPK

619.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
619.text_preview:
Use lime or preferably, dolomite (Ca + Mg) at 500 g per plant every two years and apply before
the end of the rainy season.

620.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
620.text_preview:
Use the last rains to wash the lime into the soil or water in well by
hand or irrigation.

621.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
621.text_preview:
The following table shows the nutrient uptake and consumption by different
parts of coffee tree (expected yields / ha: 1000 kg green beans). Nutrient uptake of a coffee tree
Elements (kg)
Parts of tre

622.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
622.text_preview: However, nutrients are returned to the soil when the leaves drop.

623.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
623.text_preview:
The early
years of root development are very important as branches and roots store nutrients for a long
time.

624.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
624.text_preview: Nutrients accumulated in the fruits will be removed when cherries are harvested.

625.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
625.text_preview:
This loss
needs to be compensated by the addition of fertilizers, organic manures, leaf fall or prunings
and leaves from shade trees.

626.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
626.text_preview:
Recycling of pulp to the soil after composting can help to reduce
the additional (chemical) fertiliser needed.

627.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
627.text_preview:
Fertiliser placement
While good for the soil, manure or compost
may not supply the full range and amount of
nutrients required by the coffee tree and
some mineral fertiliser or micronutrients or

othe

628.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

629.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
629.text_preview:
Place a band of fertiliser around the drip line
Spread fertiliser evenly on the soil around the drip line (the outside edge of the canopy) of the
coffee tree, as this is where most feeder/hair roots a

630.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
630.text_preview:
Keep fertiliser at
least 100 mm from the stem of the plant; fertiliser applied closer than this can damage the
coffee tree.

631.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf

632.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
632.text_preview:
The minimum amounts to apply are:
Year 2
0.7 kg/tree
Year 3
1 kg /tree
Year 4
2 kg /tree
Year 5 onwards
2.5 kg/tree
Legume shade trees, ground covers and suitable intercrops supply nutrients and organ

633.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
633.text_preview:
Nutrient deficiency symptoms
The overall rate of coffee growth and production depends on the least available plant nutrient.

634.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
634.text_preview:
Plants will grow and produce only as much as the least available nutrient will allow them to. It
does not matter how much of the other nutrients are available to the plant because it is the
least avai

635.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
635.text_preview:
This is well illustrated in the
following 'Barrel Analogy', where the barrel can hold only as much water as the shortest plank
will allow (Figure 26).

636.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
636.text_preview:
This is known as the 'Law of the Minimum' and is explained thus:

Figure 26.

637.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
637.text_preview:
'Barrel Analogy' using nitrogen as the least available nutrient
The level of water in the barrel represents the level of crop yield that is restricted by the most
limiting nutrient, nitrogen.

638.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
638.text_preview:
When nitrogen is added, the level of crop production is controlled by
the next most limiting factor (in this example, potassium).

639.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
639.text_preview: Poor nutrition is a major cause of coffee dieback.

640.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
640.text_preview:
Plants lacking sufficient N (nitrogen) and K
(potassium) suffer from dieback, especially where there is poor shade cover and insufficient
water.

641.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
641.text_preview:
Low soil calcium and phosphorus will hinder root development and contribute to
dieback.

642.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
642.text_preview:
Dieback causes loss of yield and when severe, plants can die, especially high
yielding, dwarf Catimor varieties.

643.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
643.text_preview: Each nutrient has unique deficiency symptoms.

644.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
644.text_preview:
These are briefly described below and can be
seen in the photographs.

645.filename: Arabica coffee manual for Lao incl nutrient and nitrogen requirement .pdf
645.text_preview:

originating 
in
older leaves or generally on
the whole plant.

The veins and

margins

leaves

Uniform yellowing over whole leaf or faint yellowing between leaf veins; plants
with sparse vegetative growth.

678.text_preview:
The lowest mean disease incidence was recorded in Bordeaux mixture and 
Trichoderma treated block (34%). Bordeaux mixture was found superior in managing the 
disease with lowest PDI values (80%,57%,48

679.text_preview:
Lowest mean AUDPC value and AUDPC value per day was recorded in 
block treated with Bordeaux mixture (2425.92 and 30.32) as compared to untreated check 
(4574.074 and 60.76) indicating the slower dise

680.text_preview:
Despite of the superiority 
of Bordeaux mixture in the slow progress of disease all three treatments were statistically at 
par with each other.

681.text_preview:
All the treatments were superior in controlling the disease over the 
control, among them Bordeaux mixture followed by Trichoderma is found to have superior 
efficacy in managing the disease.

682.text_preview:
KEY WORDS 
Bordeaux, PDI, coffee, trichoderma, Nepal.

683.text_preview:
Agriculture, being the major source of livelihood of majority of the Nepalese people, 
contributes about 33% to the GDP and 65.6% to employment.

684.text_preview:
Moreover, horticulture 
contributes about 14% to the total agriculture gross domestic product (World Economic 
Outlook Database, 2019).

685.text_preview:
Coffee is a high-value cash crop with important environmental implications that has 
been common among Nepalese for decades.

686.text_preview:
It has spread to more than 40 districts in 
Nepal's middle hills.

687.text_preview:
All Nepali coffee is of the Arabica variety, with a blend of bourbon and 
traditional varieties, and is cultivated by small farmers at altitudes ranging from 1000 meters 
to 1600 meters, using sustain

688.text_preview:
Selective hand 
picking of fully ripe cherries is carried out and pulped immediately after harvesting with a mini 
hand pulper (wet processing), as well as any additional procedures that may be needed

689.text_preview:
Coffee is cash crop started to be grown 
in Nepal almost with no use of inorganic fertilizer and pesticide (Agriculture Enterprise 
Centre, 2006). Coffee is cultivated mostly by resource-poor and smal

690.text_preview:
Chemical fertilizers and insecticides are seldom used in the 
production process.

691.text_preview:
Highland and organic coffee, on the other hand, are well-known in 
worldwide markets because to their high-quality cupping and fragrance.

692.text_preview:
Coffee contributes 
about 0.04 percent to GDP of Nepal (Postgraduate Student Society, 2004).

693.text_preview:
It provides 5 
times more yield than that of maize and millets and 2-3 times more yield than that of any 
other cash crops.

694.text_preview:
Coffee being a perennial cash crop started to be grown in Nepal with 
almost no use of inorganic fertilizer and pesticide (Pandit, 2015).

695.text_preview:
Coffee was first brought in Nepal by Hira Giri from Myanmar back in 1938 in Aapachaur 
village, Gulmi.

696.text_preview:
After that it remains curious plant for the several decades until his majesty's 

RJOAS, 7(127), July 2022 
112 
government decided to import coffee seeds from India in 1968.

697.text_preview:
Early 1980s considered the 
year for the significant progress in coffee farming with the development of Nepali Coffee 
Company & Coffee Development Centre under department of Agriculture in the same v

698.text_preview:
Basic coffee growing districts of Nepal are Kaski, Palpa, 
Lamjung, Gorkha, Tanahun, Syanga, Baglung, Arghakhanchi, Parvat, Kavre, Lalitpur, 
Sindhupalchock The effective assessment of the plant disea

699.text_preview:
In 
Tropical America, Africa and Asia coffee is subjected to more than 40 diseases.

700.text_preview:
These 
diseases are due to fungi, bacteria, virus, physiological disorders and mineral deficiencies.

701.text_preview:
The disease being the major constraint for the organic coffee production. Tropical America, 
Africa and Asia are subjected to more than 40 coffee diseases due to various causes like 
fungi, bacteria,

702.text_preview:
Coffee is one of the most important cash generative crops in the mid hill regions of 
Nepal.

703.text_preview:
Presently, coffee is cultivated in around 40 districts, but it has been producing 
commercially in about 20-22 hill districts (Sharma, Dhakal, Ghimire, & Rijal, 2015).

704.text_preview:
Coffee 
was first introduced to Nepal in 1938 but it took a long time for commercial plantations to be 
established in the country.

705.text_preview:
The first commercial plantation in Nepal was established in 1981, 
after which plantation growing spread to 41 districts in the country (Ranjitkar, et al., 2016).

706.text_preview:
Coffee production in Nepal has increased from 72 tons in 2000 to 639 tons in 2019 growing 
at an average annual rate of 14.79%. In 2019, coffee production for Nepal was 639 tones, an 
increase of 13.7

707.text_preview:
Coffee diseases are caused by pathogenic and micro fungi and sometimes by bacteria 
and some viruses as well. The different parts of Coffee show disease symptoms causing 
debility, deformity and somet

708.text_preview:
It affects both leaves and fruits, which is 
seems more problematic in the newly established coffee orchard and is more susceptible to 
field with plant nutrition deficiency, particularly nitrogen and

709.text_preview:
C. coffeicola symptoms differ depending on which plant 
organ is infected.

710.text_preview:
Cercospora "Leaf Spot" and Cercospora "Berry Blotch" are two of the 
disease's common names in which Cercospora is reference to the deuteromycete stage 
(Nelson, 2008).

711.text_preview:
On the top leaf surface, lesions begin as chlorotic (yellow) patches that 
develop to become deep brown and necrotic (Virginia & Scot, 2015).

712.text_preview:
Many of these spots 
have a yellow "halo" around the edges and a discolored, light center where sporulation might 
occur.

713.text_preview:
Cercospora species generate the toxin cercosporin, which causes the halo (Nelson, 
2008).

714.text_preview:
Fruit symptoms typically appear 90 days after flowering (Gaitan, 2015) On green 
berries, this includes irregularly shaped brown, sunken lesions that are surrounded by a 
purple halo.

715.text_preview: Infected red cherries also have large, dark areas of sunken flesh.

716.text_preview:
At this stage, 
fruit is susceptible to attack by opportunistic bacteria and fungi (such as Colletotrichum 
gloeosporioides), though symptoms from these organisms should not be falsely attributed to

717.text_preview:

739.text_preview:

number and size of the lesions.

DISCUSSION OF RESULTS 
 
The present work is done to disseminate simple, low cost & eco-friendly integrated 
package for this disease to farmers suitable under mid hill conditions.

All the treatments 
significantly reduced the Cercospora disease severity after first, second, third and fourth 
sprays over unsprayed control.

The result indicate that Bordeaux mixture is found to be must 
effective ecofriendly management treatments over other treatments which might be due to 
the toxicity of the copper to the pathogens as s

of Bordeaux mixture again

1420.text_preview: Downloaded from https://cabidigitallibrary.org by 2402:800:6379:1e23:9880:39f2:b6f8:ef89, on 03/09/24. Subject to the CABI Digital Library Terms & Conditions, available at https://cabidigitallibrary.

1421.text_preview:
VIETNAM
Crop Nutrition for Vietnamese Robusta Coffee
By Tassilo Tiemann, Tin Maung Aye, Nguyen Duc Dung, Tran Minh Tien, Myles Fisher, Ezio Nalin de Paulo, and Thomas Oberthür
V
ietnam is the world’s

1422.text_preview:
About 86% 
of the country’s coffee is produced in the Central 
Highlands.

1423.text_preview:
The total production of 28 to 30 million (M) 60 
kg bags is similar to that of the state of Minas Gerais, Bra­
zil’s largest producer.

1424.text_preview:
Coffee covers 582,500 ha of the Cen­
tral Highlands, which is only about 10% of the area.

1425.text_preview:
It is the 
most intensive and concentrated area of coffee production 
in the world (Baker, 2016).

1426.text_preview:
Production of Robusta coffee at this intensity exports 
substantial amounts of nutrients from the field in the green 
coffee beans and associated pulp and parchment (Table 1, 
summary by Harding, not

1427.text_preview:
There is little information 
on either nutrient recommendations or actual nutrient use 
in Robusta coffee in Vietnam. We reviewed the in-country 
literature available on Robusta coffee nutrition in th

1428.text_preview:
We also met with 
farmer focus groups in eight villages in two provinces of the 
Central Highlands.

1429.text_preview:
Our objective was to learn what their 
current fertilizer practices are and their understanding of 
nutrient management of the crop.

1430.text_preview:
SUMMARY
Coffee remains one of the most significant sources 
of income for many farmers in the Central Highlands 
of Vietnam, but at the same time, yields have 
been declining or stagnant.

1431.text_preview:
Field insights indicate 
that farmers attempt to counter this trend by 
experimenting with varying, often increasing amounts 
of currently available fertilizers.

1432.text_preview:
These changes have 
not worked but have increased production costs 
markedly.

1433.text_preview:
Not to mention that imbalanced fertilizer 
dressings cause collateral effects of increased 
contamination of offsite water resources.

1434.text_preview:
Robusta 
coffee systems in the Central Highlands of Vietnam 
have potential for improvement that can be realized 
by closing knowledge gaps on balanced crop nutrition, 
and at the same time, extending

1435.text_preview:
ABBREVIATIONS AND NOTES: 
N = nitrogen; P = phosphorus; K = potassium; Ca = calcium; 
Mg = magnesium; S = sulfur; B = boron; Zn = zinc; TE = trace 
elements; ROI = return on investment.

1436.text_preview:
https://doi.org/10.24047/BC102320
KEYWORDS:
Robusta coffee, Central Highlands, Vietnam, fertilizer use, 
nutrient imbalances.

1437.text_preview:
IPNI Project 2017 VNM-01
Dr. Tin Maung Aye (left) and Dr. Tran Minh Tien (right) inspecting a coffee field in Vietnam.

pulp, parchment, and skin.

1443.text_preview:
3) 

Farming Systems in the 
Central Highlands of Vietnam
The Highland region has two main 
soils, reddish-yellow Acrisols derived from 
acidic granites and the less common red­
dish-brown Ferralsols

1444.text_preview:
Coffee 
is mostly grown on Ferralsols (3,500 km2, 
69%) with pH 4.5 to 5.3.

1445.text_preview:
The remaining 
1,600 km2 are on Acrisols (Nguyen and 
Tran, 2017).

1446.text_preview:
Smallholders produce about 1.06 M t 
of Robusta coffee annually with an average 
yield of 2.2 t/ha dry beans.

1447.text_preview:
Of the farmers 
we interviewed, 74% generate 20 to 50% 
of their income off-farm.

1448.text_preview:
Farms are typi­
cally 1 to 2 ha, 95% in diversified systems 
that include black pepper, fruits, nuts, and livestock.

1449.text_preview:
Coffee 
is often planted with black pepper in the same farm, at a 
density of 850 to 1,200 coffee trees/ha and 1,000 to 2,500 
black pepper plants.

1450.text_preview:
Major production expenses are fertiliz­
ers (40%), pruning (25%), and harvesting (20%).

1451.text_preview:
Of all the 
crops they grow, coffee requires the most labor input.

1452.text_preview:
The region has a tropical savanna climate with a warm 
wet season between April/May and October/November, 
and a cool dry season from December to March.

1453.text_preview:
Annual 
rainfall varies between 1,200 to 2,000 mm.

1454.text_preview:
Growers com­
monly irrigate coffee during the dry season mostly by pump­
ing from sub-surface wells (Amarasinghe et al., 2015).

1455.text_preview:
Grow­
ers harvest the crop and apply some crop management in 
the dry season but do most crop management in the wet sea­
son.

1456.text_preview:
They prune the plants in January after harvest, in May 
and in July/August, each time returning pruned material 
to the field.

1457.text_preview:
Farmers apply fertilizer during the rainy season 
(April, June, and July/August), while some apply addition­
al dressings during the late rainy season or the dry season.

1458.text_preview:
Many growers irrigate 3 to 4 times during the dry season at 
20 to 25-day intervals by sprinkler or basin irrigation.

1459.text_preview:
Nematodes and mealybug are main pests and coffee 
rust is the main disease, especially mealybug and rust in the 
wettest period during June/July.

1460.text_preview:
Growers perceive weath­
er and the cost and availability of fertilizer as their biggest 
constraints.

1461.text_preview:
There is also no diversified market with qual­
ity-based pricing, and most farmers sell their beans at a 
moisture content of 15%.

1462.text_preview:
Coffee production in Vietnam became popular more 
than 20 years ago when smallholders planted large areas 
of it.

1463.text_preview:
About 60% of all coffee trees are now more than 15 
years old and will soon come to the end of their productive 
cycle.

1464.text_preview: They will need to be replaced over the next few years.

1465.text_preview:
Moreover, most of the current varieties are not well adapt­
ed to diseases and, as well, climate change will reduce their 
productivity (D’haeze et al.

1467.text_preview:
Farmers might be able to 
change to better-adapted varieties when they replant.

1468.text_preview:
Current Nutrient Removal and Fertilizer Management
The data in the few studies on nutrient removal that we 
found for Robusta coffee vary widely so that the following 
are only rough estimates.

1469.text_preview:
Using the mean of several indica­
tive data sources that Harding (not dated, Table 1) cites, the 
average yield of 2.2 t/ha on the Central Highlands with­
draws N: P: K of about 72.1: 5.1: 79.4 kg, ig

1470.text_preview:
These figures indicate the minimum requirements that soil 
and fertilizer must provide to balance the amounts lost in 
the harvested beans.

1471.text_preview:
Farmers in the survey reported yields 
almost 5 t/ha of green beans in good years, which accord­
ingly will remove 164: 11.5: 180.5 kg/ha N: P: K. At the 
same time, we also expect the harvest to expo

1472.text_preview:
Current government guidelines for coffee include rec­
ommendations for nutrient management, which we used as 
the reference base (Tables 2 and 3).

1473.text_preview:
These recommenda­
tions, however, are based on a relatively small number of re­
search studies, mainly on rates of NPK fertilizers.

1475.text_preview: Existing fertilizer recommendation for Robusta coffee in Vietnam (kg/ha/yr).

1477.text_preview:
TAKE IT TO THE FIELD
Fertilizer applications are unbalanced.

1478.text_preview:
The 
motivation of farmers to apply in this manner 
was not fully explained by field interviews, 
but it is likely related to limited options within 
the portfolio of fertilizers available, incomplete

1479.text_preview:
Any future 
field trials and nutrient management campaigns need to address 
these interrelated issues.

1483.text_preview:
Subject to the CABI Digital Library Terms & Conditions, available at https://cabidigitallibrary.org/terms-and-conditions

are largely deduced from yield-based estimates of nutrients 
in the harvested

1484.text_preview:
There is little information on the best application 
schedules, or nutrient sources.

1485.text_preview:
Furthermore, growers do not 
use nutrients such as Mg, Zn, and B.

1486.text_preview:
There are therefore 
important knowledge gaps in applying the 4R concept of 
the right source, rate, time, and place for managing fertilizer 
for coffee in the Central Highlands.

1487.text_preview:
Experiments showed that combined application of fused 
magnesium phosphate (for base application) and diammo­
nium phosphate (for topdressing) gave large and sustainable 
coffee yields.

1488.text_preview:
Diammonium phosphate alone was less suit­
able as a P source due to its fast release peak of 30 days.

1489.text_preview:
Fused magnesium phosphate and diammonium phosphate 
gave good results in early years, however, single superphos­
phate was better in mature stands.

1490.text_preview:
Farmers apply NPK and NPK+S most­
ly using a range of low density compound 
fertilizers because they require less labor.

1491.text_preview:
They rarely apply single nutrient fertilizers 
and seem to have little information about 
the characteristics of different NPK for­
mulations.

1492.text_preview:
Most farmers lack clarity about 
nutrient requirements and the role of bal­
anced nutrient supply.

1493.text_preview:
Rates and ratios 
of applied nutrients vary widely (Tables 
4 and 5).

1494.text_preview:
In general, farmers apply nutri­
ents in excess, sometimes by as much as 
four times the recommended rates.

1495.text_preview:
Official 
recommendations, which aim to provide a 
balanced supply of nutrients, are seldom 
followed.

1496.text_preview:
Farmers apply fertilizer 3 to 5 times each year, but the 
rates vary across times.

1497.text_preview:
Rates of N and S are more or less 
constant at 120 kg N/ha and 70 to 80 kg S/ha.

1498.text_preview:
Farmers 
apply P mainly in the rainy season at about 80 kg/ha.

1499.text_preview:
Mg, 
if applied at all, is given in April/May, at the onset of the 
rainy season.

1500.text_preview:
Farmers apply K starting with 25 kg/ha in the 
dry season (February) and increasing it to about 140 kg/ha 
in July to October.

1501.text_preview:
Although these are the averages across 
all the farmers that we interviewed, they show that most of 
them apply fertilizer during the wet season.

1502.text_preview:
Soils in the Central Highlands are rather infertile, with 
low cation exchange capacity, which limits their ability to 
store and provide nutrients (Tien et al., 2015).

1503.text_preview:
Applied nu­
trients leach readily during the rainy season, so that it is ad­
visable to limit fertilizer applications during this season.

1504.text_preview:
It 
might be efficient to apply more fertilizer during the dry 
season using frequent, careful irrigation.

1505.text_preview:
Some nutrients are 
rarely applied and twenty years of intensive production of 
Robusta coffee may have mined soil nutrients not supplied 
by external sources.

1506.text_preview:
A sustainable production system must 
replace nutrient losses in addition to those removed with 
the crop.

1507.text_preview:
Recommendations to farmers must address these 
requirements and consider also the crop’s nutrient use effi­
ciency (NUE).

1508.text_preview:
Understanding the Potential 
Return on Investment from Fertilizer
We compared the farmers’ relative income, fertilizer al­
location, and production costs (Figure 1), and found a pic­
ture of lost oppo

1509.text_preview:
Relative production costs of coffee 
are generally higher than the relative contribution of coffee 
to overall farm income (Figure 1A).

1510.text_preview:
This indicates that the 
ROI is currently lower for coffee than for other farm ac­
tivities.

1511.text_preview:
At the same time, the relative amount of fertilizer 
applied to coffee is much larger than coffee’s relative con­
Table 3.

1523.text_preview:
Subject to the CABI Digital Library Terms & Conditions, available at https://cabidigitallibrary.org/terms-and-conditions

tribution to household income (Figure 1B).

1524.text_preview:
This is in line 
with the perception of farmers that fertilizer application is 
the most resource intensive amongst the agronomic prac­
tices deployed to coffee.

1525.text_preview:
Hence, there is potential for large 
improvement in economic efficiency.

1526.text_preview:
The low production 
cost/high income (lower right) quadrant of Figure 1A, 
which contains no data points, confirms this conclusion.

1527.text_preview: How Can Improved Economic Efficiency Be Achieved?

1528.text_preview:
It is not entirely clear why growers apply large amounts 
of fertilizer in an unbalanced manner.

1529.text_preview:
Field insights indi­
cate that yields are highly variable, declining or stagnant in 
recent years, and farmers may attempt to counter this trend 
by experimenting with varying, often increasing amount

1530.text_preview:
Some of the decline is likely 
not even related to nutrient management, but due to trees 
nearing the end of their production cycle, possibly wors­
ened by increasing pest and disease pressure.

1531.text_preview:
These chang­
es in nutrient management have not worked, but increased 
production costs markedly.

1532.text_preview:
Nutrient imbalance is a likely 
contributor to stagnating variable yields, with sub-optimal 
Mg, Ca, and micronutrients strong candidates.

1533.text_preview:
Farmers do 
not seem to have access to sufficient fertilizer formulations 
addressing this.

1534.text_preview:
Not to mention that imbalanced fertilizer 
dressings cause collateral effects of increased contamination 
of offsite water resources.

1535.text_preview:
We conclude that Robusta coffee systems in the Cen­
tral Highlands of Vietnam have large potential for im­
provement.

1536.text_preview:
Nutrient management may provide multiple 
opportunities for change by contributing to stabilized yields 
(reducing the good - bad year variability), improved crop 
quality, reduced environmental impac

1537.text_preview:
Key to success is likely addressing imbal­
anced nutrition and introducing nutrients into the system 
that are currently lacking.

1538.text_preview:
Additional research is required to 
generate the knowledge needed to realize this potential.

1539.text_preview:

1624.filename: Cercospora Leaf Spot and Berry Blotch of Coffee (2008, Hawaii).pdf

1627.filename: Cercospora Leaf Spot and Berry Blotch of Coffee (2008, Hawaii).pdf
1627.text_preview:
Lesions are sometimes surrounded or ringed by a 
bright yellowish “halo,” which is more visibly apparent on 
the upper leaf surface.

1628.text_preview:
Dark-colored and silvery-colored 
sporulation of the pathogen may be visible to the naked 
eye within the grayish-white centers of lesions.

1631.filename: Cercospora Leaf Spot and Berry Blotch of Coffee (2008, Hawaii).pdf

Large, sunken, blackened areas develop, which may be 
covered with a silvery sheen of fungal spores.

field, do not pile it up against the plants in the field or 
leave it between rows (leaf a

ing winds, so plant canopies and

At high, cloudy, wet altitudes (>2000 ft) in Hawai‘i, leaf 
spots may become leaf blights, causing more damage (right).

1655.filename: Cercospora Leaf Spot and Berry Blotch of Coffee (2008, Hawaii).pdf
1655.text_preview:
•	 Strive to minimize plant stresses such as drought, 
under-nutrition, planting on impermeable rock out-
croppings, root-knot nematodes, and root rot; these 
predispose coffee plants to infection.

1656.filename: Cercospora Leaf Spot and Berry Blotch of Coffee (2008, Hawaii).pdf
1656.text_preview:
•	 Provide or ensure adequate soil drainage (this mini-
mizes root rot).

1657.filename: Cercospora Leaf Spot and Berry Blotch of Coffee (2008, Hawaii).pdf
1657.text_preview:
•	 Grow coffee under shade (35–65%), or in an agrofor-
estry setting.

1658.filename: Cercospora Leaf Spot and Berry Blotch of Coffee (2008, Hawaii).pdf
1658.text_preview:
•	 Avoid over-irrigation (this will minimize plant stresses 
such as root rot and will reduce relative humidity 
within the plant canopy).

1659.filename: Cercospora Leaf Spot and Berry Blotch of Coffee (2008, Hawaii).pdf
1659.text_preview:
•	 Avoid working with coffee plants and moving through 
fields and nurseries when diseased plants are wet (this 
minimizes potential dispersal of fungal conidia within 
and among moist plants).

1660.filename: Cercospora Leaf Spot and Berry Blotch of Coffee (2008, Hawaii).pdf
1660.text_preview:
•	 Prune coffee trees to increase air circulation in the 
canopy.

1661.filename: Cercospora Leaf Spot and Berry Blotch of Coffee (2008, Hawaii).pdf
1661.text_preview:
•	 Harvest cherries on time, before disease progresses 
too far.

1662.filename: Cercospora Leaf Spot and Berry Blotch of Coffee (2008, Hawaii).pdf
1662.text_preview:
•	 Avoid injuring coffee plants with herbicides, especially 
glyphosate (plants injured by this herbicide may be 
more susceptible to infection due to nutritional defi-
ciencies).

1663.filename: Cercospora Leaf Spot and Berry Blotch of Coffee (2008, Hawaii).pdf
1663.text_preview:
•	 Control weeds (this minimizes plant stress and relative 
humidity in the plant canopy).

1664.filename: Cercospora Leaf Spot and Berry Blotch of Coffee (2008, Hawaii).pdf
1664.text_preview:
•	 Apply fungicide sprays to foliage where environmen-
tal conditions are particularly conducive to infection 
and disease development (please refer to Fungicide 
Recommendations below).

1665.filename: Cercospora Leaf Spot and Berry Blotch of Coffee (2008, Hawaii).pdf
1665.text_preview: •	 Avoid planting coffee transplants too deep in soils.

1666.filename: Cercospora Leaf Spot and Berry Blotch of Coffee (2008, Hawaii).pdf
1666.text_preview:
•	 Protect new coffee foliage re-growth with fungicide 
sprays after pruning (immature leaves are more sus-
ceptible to infection than mature leaves).

1667.filename: Cercospora Leaf Spot and Berry Blotch of Coffee (2008, Hawaii).pdf
1667.text_preview:
Fungicide options
In Hawai‘i, copper fungicides such as Kocide products 
(see table) are normally used against this pathogen.

1668.filename: Cercospora Leaf Spot and Berry Blotch of Coffee (2008, Hawaii).pdf
1668.text_preview:
It is 
important to protect the fruits from the leaf phase of the 
disease.

1669.filename: Cercospora Leaf Spot and Berry Blotch of Coffee (2008, Hawaii).pdf
1669.text_preview:
For Kocide 101 products, use from 1.5–6 pounds 
of product per acre in 50–100 gallons of water.

1680.filename: Cercospora Leaf Spot and Berry Blotch of Coffee (2008, Hawaii).pdf
1680.text_preview:

hormone that is also produced by some plant-pathogenic 
fungi during infection and disease development.

Overview of practice 
Coffee-Banana Itercropping is a

increases farmer incomes, improves

positive effects for rural women and 
household nutrition.

Coffee-Banana Intercropping (CBI) 
addresses all 3 pillars of CSA in a

generates 50% more revenue than 
either coffee or banana monocrop.

PRACTICE BRIEF | CLIMATE-SMART AGRICULTURE 
Overview of practice  
Arabica (Coffea arabica) and Robusta (Coffea 
canephora), the two main types of coffee, offer 
the promise of a better life for 20

1744.text_preview:
Coffee is a 
major export crop and an important source of 
foreign revenue in most tropical and subtropical 
regions, including the Great Lakes Region of 
Eastern and Central Africa.

1745.text_preview:
These same farmers 
also depend on bananas (Musa spp.)

1746.text_preview:
for food 
security and additional income throughout the 
year.

1747.text_preview:
Yet, the prevalence of seasonal food 
insecurity in many coffee growing communities 
suggests a lack of resources for smallholder 
coffee farmers to feed themselves and their 
families (Caswell et al.

1748.text_preview:
Climate change is indisputably having negative 
effects on global crop yields and threatening 
food security.

1749.text_preview:
The key issues facing the coffee 
sector, including declining productivity, price 
volatility and terms of trade, have been 
compounded by increased temperature change.

1750.text_preview:
Recent evidence shows that climate change is 
having substantial impact on the areas suitable 
for cultivation of Arabica coffee in the major 
growing regions, including the East African 
Highlands re

1751.text_preview:
In Uganda, for example, 
the National Planning Authority (NPA) 
considered a scenario in which coffee 
production could be entirely wiped out in less 
than 100 years (NPA, 2010).

1752.text_preview:
Consequences for 
national income and livelihoods for millions of 
smallholder farmers in the region are dramatic, 
with losses estimated at USD 100 million in 
revenue per year (Rijsberman, 2015).

1753.text_preview:
This calls for immediate action through 
increased investment in climate change 
adaptation strategies in coffee-based systems, 
something that has been stressed over the past 
years.

1754.text_preview:
Coffee intercropping with shade trees is 
recognized among the promising adaptation 
practices capable of compensating for higher 
canopy temperatures by 2°C to 3°C (Ovalle-
Rivera et al., 2015).

1755.text_preview:
Apparently, the extensive 
time lag (5-10 years) for the establishment of 
shade trees is a major barrier to substantial 
adoption by many smallholders.

1756.text_preview:
Conversely, 
bananas normally attain their full canopy cover 
within 6-12 months, and hence intercropping 
with banana is the most promising climate 
change adaptation approaches for coffee today.

1757.text_preview:

novel approach per se, it is a traditional 
practice developed by smallholder farmers over 
decades (Ekong, 2015), as a coping strategy to

CBI is very diverse in nature and widely 
practiced in the East African highlands, and 
across the humid tropics, including Latin-
America, Asia and West Africa.

1759.text_preview:
Both crops can 
be planted at the same time.

1760.text_preview:
Alternatively, 
coffee can be introduced in existing banana 
plantations but banana population may need to 
be thinned to provide sufficient space for the 
coffee trees. Similarly, banana can be plant

1761.text_preview:
Official recommendations from public extension 
and research bodies differ significantly, with 
optimum banana densities being highly variable 
within and between locations.

and Burundi, had banned farmers from 
intercropping coffee with banana, in the

its beneficial triple-wins of increasing food

Main methodological inconsistencies: the modelling of the perennial crop, the biomass accounting, 
including Land Use and Land Use Change (LULUC), and the handling of co-products.

2028.text_preview:
Analysis of existing Carbon Footprint guidelines: 
• 
Main useful standards are the CFP-PCR (2013) for green coffee and the ISO 14067 for Carbon 
Footprinting.

enough.

2036.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2036.text_preview:
Recommendations on the perennial cycle modelling: 
• 
We recommend the modelling of the whole perennial cycle based on a modular approach.

2037.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2037.text_preview:
Each module 
consists in a perennial development phase that should be characterised by an average dataset and 
multiplied by the phase duration.

2038.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2038.text_preview:
Inputs/outputs over the whole cycle are calculated as a weighted 
average.

2039.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2039.text_preview:
• 
The number of phases and their respective durations may be site-specific but with a minimum of 3 
phases.

2040.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2040.text_preview:
Uncertainty related to the phase durations and data quality may be tested through scenario 
analysis.

2041.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2041.text_preview:
• 
For each phase, data should be collected for 2-3 consecutive years in order to smooth out climate 
variability.

2042.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2042.text_preview:
• 
Nursery may be considered negligible from a carbon footprint point of view except for 3 specified cases: 
greenhouse nurseries; coffee density >5000 trees/ha; and coffee plantation <10 years lifesp

2043.text_preview:
Recommendations on LULUC accounting: 
• 
We recommend applying IPCC 2006 Tier 1, Stock difference approach for both LUC and LU emissions, 
with a consistent 20-year timeframe applied for.

LUC should be considered when occurring within the 
past 20 years; likewise, increased stocks within coffee plantations (i.e.

2045.text_preview:
LU) should only be considered if 
the management changes leading to increased stocks have been consistently applied for at least 20 
years.

2046.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2046.text_preview:
Carbon stocks should be based on previous recommendations regarding biomass quantification 
and should be time-averaged in order to smooth out the long-term variations in planting cycles.

Recommendations on biomass estimation: 
• 
We provide a range of allometric models to estimate the above and below-ground biomass of coffee 
trees and associated trees.

These must be combined with tree densities and averaged over the whole 
duration of the coffee plantation.

2059.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2059.text_preview:
• 
The biomass of associated trees is by far the largest pool of perennial biomass in agroforestry systems, 
higher than that of coffee trees, especially in complex agroforestry systems.

2060.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

but the range for coarse root is about 40 %. Additional studies with robust methodologies in a vari

Therefore, the large recalcitrant fraction can 
contribute directly to long-term C sequestration in soil.

However, on the basis of current knowledge, it 
is not possible to say precisely for how long and with what long-term consequences for agro-
ecosystems.

or biogenic origin.

originates from atmospheric CO2 and returns to the atmosphere quickly 
enough so as not to modify the greenhouse effect.

2.2 Review on carbon footprint guidelines and harmonised parameters  
We reviewed the key methodological guidelines applied to LCA and carbon footprint.

2483.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2483.text_preview:
These 
guidelines are internationally recognised as fundamental to ensure the reliability of results.

2484.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2484.text_preview:
After the 
ﬁrst life cycle assessments in the early 1980s, LCA gained more traction in the 1990s with the 
development of bioenergy.

2485.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2485.text_preview:
However, at that stage the lack of harmonisation in the methods led to 
confusing results, varying upon the methods applied more than the data used, as highlighted in a 
seminal publication by Farrell

2486.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2486.text_preview: (2006) looking back at contradictory corn ethanol LCA studies.

2487.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2487.text_preview:
This 
confusion called for an unprecedented international harmonisation regarding environmental 
assessment, particularly through the structuring and formalisation work led by SETAC16.

2488.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2488.text_preview:
Since the early 2000s, LCA has become a standardised conceptual and methodological framework 
under ISO series 14040 (2000–2006).

2489.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2489.text_preview: It is based on two fundamental principles.

2490.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2490.text_preview:
First, environmental 
impacts are quantiﬁed throughout the supply chain or ‘life cycle’, from raw material extraction 
(‘cradle’) to end-of-life of the product or service (‘grave’).

2491.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2491.text_preview:
Then, the impacts are quantiﬁed with respect 
to a functional unit, either a product quantity (one kilo, one car, etc.)

2492.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2492.text_preview:
or a usage or service (hours, 
kilometres, etc.).

2493.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2493.text_preview:
In that way, the environmental impacts of systems producing a similar function can 
be compared.

2494.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2494.text_preview:
Thus, LCA has become the worldwide standard for implementing environmental product 
declarations (ISO 14025:2006 Type III Environmental Declarations).

2495.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2495.text_preview:
ISO standards were defined, and 
translated into various languages, in order to make sure these fundamental principles and steps in 
application are commonly respected.

2496.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

2497.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2497.text_preview:
Further 14000 series ISO standards were developed, notably the ISO 14067 (2013) with relation to 
single issue LCA focusing on global warming assessment or carbon footprint.

2498.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2498.text_preview:
Besides, further guidelines 
were derived from the seminal ISO standards to provide sector wise declinations and practical 
information also called Product Categories Rules (PCR).

2499.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2499.text_preview:

emissions of UN CPC 01610 (Green coffee) has expired in 2016, but was considered as a central 
guideline

processes taking place at different locations and time points, it represents a snapshot of a product 
system, whose validity is limited to the defined scope.

Besides the “mere amount” of a functional unit 
(e.g.

1 kg green coffee), details on its scope should be provided when introducing the study goal and 
scope (e.g.

2521.text_preview:
1 kg green coffee provided at farm gate by X on average in 2020 - see recommendations 
below).

2522.text_preview:
Therefore, it is important to bear in mind that LCA results for a given functional unit may vary 
due to variations in the scope that may not be properly considered or elicited within this functional

The scope of the system boundary is adjusted through an iterative process, whereby all processes 
and flows should be first considered and only discarded if it can be demonstrated that their

2524.text_preview:
Transparency is a key principle and all 
assumptions and decisions along the LCA stages need to be made crystal clear and justified.

2525.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2525.text_preview:
The final LCA results should be interpreted in light of adequacy of the system boundary to the study 
goal and scope, as well as the quality of data used relative to the study scope (e.g.

2526.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2526.text_preview:
data on Brazilian 
arabica coffee may not be suitable for a study in another country, also commonly found in the 
literature).

2527.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2527.text_preview:
The CFP-PCR (2013) - further referred to as CFP-PCR only - recommends a description of the 
production system (organic, polyculture, monoculture…) and the number of trees per hectare for 
coffee trees

2528.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2528.text_preview:
Functional Unit 
A proper FU should address the “what,” “how much,” “how well,” and “how long.” The quality of 
products is not considered in some of the PEFCR (Pedersen-Remmen 2022).

2529.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2529.text_preview:
For green-coffee, the CFP-
PCR recommends: 1 kg of Green Coffee at 11.5% moisture delivered to port of origin or the roaster’s 
warehouse if processing domestically.

2530.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2530.text_preview:
As recalled before, it is paramount that the FU reflects the study 
goal and scope and vice versa.

2531.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2531.text_preview:
System boundaries  
Green coffee carbon footprint can either be from cradle to the ’port of origin’ or from cradle to the 
warehouse of the domestic roasting facility studies.

2532.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2532.text_preview:
A sub-system at farm gate can be found in the 
literature, notably when first processing takes place on-farm.

2533.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2533.text_preview:
However, it may be confusing as further 
stages up to green coffee, such as processing or final coffee grading and sorting usually go beyond the 
farm.

2534.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2534.text_preview:
The inclusion or not of such final stages and potential intermediary transports should be specified 
and reflected within the study goal and scope and the functional unit.

2535.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2535.text_preview:
It is usually more efficient to list all the included stages and processes, rather than trying to make 
an exhaustive list of excluded ones.

2536.text_preview:
Based on past experience with agricultural and coffee-specific LCA 
no relevant processes, the CFP-PCR provides a summary of activities that should be covered: 
• 
All relevant upstream processes of i

2537.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2537.text_preview: A common exclusion in agricultural LCA are the capital goods.

2538.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2538.text_preview:
All reviewed standards agree that 
capital goods are to be excluded.

2539.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2539.text_preview:
Capital goods are input to the system, such as machines or buildings,

31 
 
with a lifespan greater than 3 years (CFP-PCR).

2540.text_preview:
Conversely, any input/consumable whose lifespan is 
less than or equal to 3 years should be included.

2541.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2541.text_preview:
For instance, irrigation pump manufacture may be 
excluded but not the manufacture of irrigation pipes that may be changed regularly (if their lifespan is 
less or equal to 3 years).

2542.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2542.text_preview:
The impact of such capital goods is usually negligible due to their long lifespan 
(more than 20 years for most infrastructure) and large throughputs, whereby only a negligible amount 
of their total

2543.text_preview:
Only the manufacture and installation of such capital 
goods are excluded.

2544.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2544.text_preview:
Impacts related to their daily use and regular maintenance are included in the LCA 
in proportions to their use to fulfil the functional unit.

2545.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2545.text_preview: Another common exclusion is human energy inputs (CFP-PCR).

2546.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2546.text_preview:
The main reason is the difficulty to 
allocate human caloric expense to a given functional unit considering other daily activities and the 
great variability of individual metabolisms and labour costs

Although simple by essence, the cut-off rule is a fuzzy concept in LCA because it applies at system 
boundary stage but should be based on quantified information further down the LCA cal

Cut 
off rule varies slightly between standards.

2549.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2549.text_preview:
At least 95% of climate change potential associated with the 
declared unit shall be included according to the CFP-PCR.

2550.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2550.text_preview:
The same cut off value is used in the PAS2050, 
where it is specified that the cut-off applies to the anticipated GHG emissions and removals.

2551.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2551.text_preview:
It indeed 
raises the question of how to accurately anticipate (<5% error) all contributions without actually 
making a full inventory.

2552.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2552.text_preview:
In the PCR for Moka, it is specified that the cut-off should be checked based 
on a combination of expert judgement and a sensitivity analysis demonstrating how the un-
investigated input or output co

2553.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2553.text_preview:
But this latter sensitivity analysis requires to 
be able to still quantify the cut-off flows.

2554.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2554.text_preview:
Besides, the PCR for Moka sets a higher cut off value with a 
minimum of 99% of the environmental impacts that shall be included.

2555.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2555.text_preview:
In practical terms, decisions on 
cut-offs should be adjusted along an iterative process.

2556.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2556.text_preview:
Where cut-offs are as low as 1-5% and need to 
be justified on quantitative analyses, they do not translate into an actual criterion to reduce the LCI 
workload.

2557.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2557.text_preview:
LCA scope and sampling approach 
The scope is quite critical in agricultural LCA, as agricultural systems are much less homogeneous 
than industrial systems (for which LCA was originally developed).

2558.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2558.text_preview:
The scope of a coffee LCA will be very 
different if the objective is to analyse one farm, a national average or a roaster supply area for instance.

2559.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2559.text_preview:
As mentioned earlier, LCI data need to be adapted to the goal and scope, meaning representative of 
the actual studied system in all its dimensions (geographical, temporal and technical).

2560.text_preview:
Given the great 
variability in coffee farming and first processing systems (c.f.

section 2.1), defining the sampling

reducing the number of farms that must be sampled to reach an acceptable margin of error.

The reporting must clearly state the approach applied, the sample size and how this was

The time dimension is one of the most complex dimensions to apprehend in LCA, which is time-
disconnected by nature due to the integrated snapshot (except for dynamics LCA).

2.3.1 Biomass estimation and allometric data    
Biogenic carbon is stored in the above- and belowground biomass of the coffee plantation (coffee 
bushes and other trees) among other carbon pools.

2728.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2728.text_preview:
Biometric measurements of bushes or trees are 
converted into biomass values using empirical allometric models.

2729.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2729.text_preview:
An allometric model is a 
mathematical equation that allows relating one or more easily measured variables (for example 
diameter at 15 cm for coffee bushes or diameter at breast height for shade tree

2730.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2730.text_preview:
Such 
allometric equations are therefore commonly used to assess the above- and belowground biomass.

2731.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2731.text_preview:
In 
this section we reviewed the existing estimations and ways to assess these two pools of carbon.

2732.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2732.text_preview:

Field measurements of above-ground and below-ground biomass in Arabica coffee trees have 
yielded several allometric models, fitted with either the measured stem diameter, coff

2733.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

maximum accuracy (Segura 2006, Andrade 2018, Negash 2013).

2734.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2734.text_preview:

stumped coffee trees, large stumps prevent these measurements close to the ground, in which case 
the diameters are measured on top of the stump and at the base of n

2735.text_preview:
The stump biomass can then be estimated separately from the other 
tree components (Segura 2006, Defrenet 2016).

2736.text_preview:

some authors tend to favour the use of basal area to aggregate the multiple stems of one coffee plant 
before fitting their allometric model (Defrene

2737.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2737.text_preview:
We only found one allometric 
model fitted on stem circumferences (Guillemot 2018).

in mass of dry matter (DM) (Figure 11).

2.3.1.3 Shade trees 
In agroforestry systems, most of the above-ground biomass belongs to shade trees.

2773.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
2773.text_preview:
The precise 
estimation of standing biomass in shade trees is thus more impactful to the total carbon balance than 
the precise estimation of biomass in coffee trees.

and the large range of growing conditions increase the complexity of analysis.

In the section below, we 
divide shade tree species into two categories: fruit trees vs other trees.

biomass.
