various contrasted pedo-climatic conditions and coffee plantations.

3416.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3416.text_preview:
The duration of this first trial 
should be at least 10 years, with first preliminary results analysed after 5 years.

3417.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3417.text_preview:
Further trials may be 
established once first results are analysed, in order to test further variables, notably the combination 
with various types and doses of fertilisers, both mineral and organic.

3418.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3418.text_preview:
In the trials, the minimum set of measured variables on an annual basis would be : 
• 
Coffee yields ; 
• 
pH, bulk density (with cylinders), and SOC (dry combustion) over the first 0-20 cm ; 
• 
Biof

3419.text_preview:
POXC, aggregate stability) over the first 0-20 
cm (Thoumazeau et al., 2019b; a).

3420.text_preview:
Further measurements should be : 
• 
GHG emissions (CO2, N2O, possibly CH4) with static chambers (at leat 2 measurements per 
day continuously over 2-3 years) ; 

Cirad report 
89 
 
• 
SOC (dry combu

3421.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3421.text_preview:
3.6 Recommendation on the handling of co-products 
Table 11 and Table 12 detail possible management pathways for coproducts from green coffee 
processing.

3422.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3422.text_preview:
These flows could be handled as a “waste” to be dealt with or as marketable raw materials 
for other value chains, such as livestock, bioenergy or biorefinery.

3423.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3423.text_preview:
In principle, and inspired by Circular 
Economy principles, the concept of cascading should be privileged: to obtain as many and diverse 
benefits as possible from a “waste” stream (Campbell-Johnston

3424.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

3425.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

3426.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3426.text_preview:
This 
implies, for the green coffee value chain, to prefer, when possible, co-product handling pathways that 
enable the recovery of chemicals, nutrients, materials and finally energy.

3427.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3427.text_preview:
For the sake of simplicity, we included in “co-products”, all other outputs from the green coffee 
supply chain, i.e.

3428.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3428.text_preview: from associated crops to residues or process waste.

3429.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3429.text_preview:
Ultimately, emissions related to 
a co-product do not only depend on the nature of a co-product (or type) but on its fate and whether it 
needs a treatment and can be recycled or not.

3430.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3430.text_preview:
The management of co-products, hence how to handle 
their GHG emissions, can vary according to local conditions.

3431.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3431.text_preview:
Concerning carbon footprint procedures, 
three cases of management can be considered to appraise various co-products within a given coffee 
supply chain: 
• 
Waste: Co-products are not used and are de

3432.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3432.text_preview:
In this case, all emissions 
related to transportation, waste management and disposal must be included.

3433.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3433.text_preview:
• 
Closed-loop valorisation: Co-products are used for another activity inside the system 
boundaries (e.g.

3434.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3434.text_preview:
application of organic waste such as husk as fertiliser on coffee 
plantations).

3435.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3435.text_preview:
In this case, GHG emissions from all steps required from production to 
valorisation must be included (e.g.

3436.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3436.text_preview:
transportation, composting, field emissions from 
application, etc.).

3437.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3437.text_preview:
• 
Open-loop valorisation: Co-products are used for an activity outside the coffee system 
boundaries (e.g.

3438.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3438.text_preview: associated crop outputs or chemical extraction from coffee residues).

3439.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3439.text_preview:
In 
this case, an allocation or system expansion issue arises.

3440.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3440.text_preview:
Allocation or system expansion 
procedures were described in section 2.2 according to the ISO and PCR guidelines.

3441.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3441.text_preview:
One should notice that co-product handling has been a matter of controversy in the LCA community 
since the very beginning due to the combined issue of varying interpretation of concepts and guideline

3442.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

3443.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf

3444.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3444.text_preview:
2023), and the tremendous influence of the 
contrasted choices.

3445.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3445.text_preview:
Co-product handling implies subjective choices and uncertainties that cannot be 
simply objectified.

3446.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3446.text_preview:
We hence do not make any further recommendation on those choices but insist on 
the need for mass balance consistency and co-product handling transparency, as both are guardrails 
for interpretation a

3447.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3447.text_preview:
Where co-products may lead to 
open-loop valorisation, one should carry out some sensitivity analysis on how various choices 
(allocation ratios and/or system expansion) would affect the final results

3448.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3448.text_preview:
Hence, the key element in any carbon footprint is the construction of a mass balance table that 
enables the identification of all potential co-products and their management as waste, close- or open-

3449.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3449.text_preview:
This table should list all carbon partitioning within the system, considering all co-
products and their relative humidity.

3450.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3450.text_preview:
Once the mass balance is established, and all co-products and 
other mass and energy flows accounted for, a baseline scenario representing the current stable state 
of the system should be constructed

3451.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3451.text_preview: Table 11 and Table 12 are not exhaustive, as multiple alternative pathways exist.

3452.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3452.text_preview:
For instance, we 
retained the most likely storage and composting technologies.

3453.text_preview:
Moreover, both tables present a 
selection of key emission factors.

3454.text_preview:
For a complete list of IPCC emission factors please refer to the online 
IPCC emission factor database (https://www.ipcc-nggip.iges.or.jp/EFDB/) as well as Table 9 and Table 
10.

3469.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3469.text_preview:
Across those studies, the median carbon footprint was 3.6 kgCO2eq/kg green coffee (min: 
0.15 kgCO2eq/kg green coffee; max: 14.5 kgCO2eq/kg green coffee).

3470.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3470.text_preview:
Unsurprisingly, N-fertilisers were the main 
common contributors, besides land use change, with some cropping systems penalised through too low or too 
high fertiliser inputs.

3471.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3471.text_preview:
But differences across studies were mostly driven by discrepancies in the methodologies 
and data used, which overwhelmed the potential intrinsic effect of contrasted production systems.

3472.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3472.text_preview:
Main 
inconsistencies concerned the modelling of the perennial crop, the biomass accounting, including LULUC, and 
the handling of co-products (including residues and processing waste).

3473.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3473.text_preview:
We further investigated these aspects in 
order to provide sound and practical recommendations based on the state-of-the-art.

3474.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3474.text_preview:
The reviewed guidelines included baseline LCA and Carbon footprint ISO standards, as well as Product 
Category Rules specific to coffee.

3475.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3475.text_preview:
Guidelines all agree on the fundamental principles and main recommendations 
but are sometimes not precise enough, especially when choices arise that cannot be strictly objective, e.g.

3476.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3476.text_preview:
when 
dealing with system multifunctionality or time integration.

3477.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3477.text_preview:
We recommend to apply ISO 14067 and Coffee PCR 
as far as possible and to consider Cirad recommendations to further increase the robustness and thoroughness 
of the assessment.

3478.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3478.text_preview: We particularly emphasise on the consistency of the perennial cycle and the LULUC modelling.

3479.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3479.text_preview:
Such modelling challenges raise recurrent issues in life-cycle based assessment for agricultural systems given the 
difficulty to integrate the time dimension in an assessment snapshot, although time

3480.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3480.text_preview:
Nevertheless, when properly considering and displaying assumptions made on the time dimension, 
including how it affects carbon biogenic inclusion or not, consistent and reproducible assessments are m

3481.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3481.text_preview:
We completed the methodological recommendations with in-depth scientific reviews on knowledge 
and data available for quantifying biomass increment and stocks as well as emissions to the environment a

3482.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3482.text_preview:
In any life-cycle based assessment, the transparency on the exact system boundaries and all embedded 
assumptions is a key principle.

3483.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3483.text_preview:
Life-cycles are complex and sometimes impossible to fully grasp; their modelling 
require simplification and choices.

3484.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3484.text_preview:
All choices embedded in the goal and scope of a study may have a critical 
impact on the results.

3485.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3485.text_preview:
One may always bear in mind that LCA or carbon footprint results remain potential impacts 
(no absolute or true results) that intrinsically depend on the study design, i.e.

3486.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3486.text_preview:
how the studied system is 
simplified, the reliability and precision of data used, and the known and unknown involved mechanisms.

3487.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3487.text_preview:
Therefore, the results are not as important as what can be learnt from testing their robustness and how they 
change depending on methodological choices as well as on the data quality.

3488.filename: CIRAD - Dec 2023 - Coffee LCA and carbon emission review and reco.pdf
3488.text_preview:
Those results must be used as 
monitoring tools and be regularly updated as soon as more knowledge or better data is available.

4112.text_preview:
For the construction of the models, a meteorological 
data set spanning of 18 years and multiple linear regressions were used.

4113.text_preview:
The models were calibrated in high‑ 
and low-yield seasons due to the high-biennial yields in Brazil.

4114.text_preview:
All calibrated models for high- and low-yield 
seasons were accurate and significant at 5% probability, with mean absolute percentage errors ≤2.9%.

4115.text_preview:
The 
minimum forecasting period for yield is six months for southern Minas Gerais and Cerrado Mineiro.

4116.text_preview:
In 
high‑yield seasons, water deficits affect more the reproductive stage of coffee and, in low-yield seasons, they 
affect more the vegetative stage of the crop.

4117.text_preview: Index terms: Coffea arabica, agrometeorology, climate, forecasting, model, water balance.

4118.text_preview:
Previsão de produtividade anual de café arábica por meio do deficit hídrico
Resumo – O objetivo deste trabalho foi desenvolver modelos agrometeorológicos para a previsão da 
produtividade anual de caf

4119.text_preview:
Para a construção dos modelos, foram 
utilizados um conjunto de dados meteorológicos com abrangência de 18 anos e regressões lineares múltiplas.

4120.text_preview:
Os modelos foram calibrados em anos de alta e baixa produtividade, em razão de a bienalidade da cultura 
ser elevada no Brasil.

4121.text_preview:
Todos os modelos calibrados para anos de alta e baixa produtividade foram acurados e 
significativos a 5% de probabilidade, com média de erros percentuais absolutos ≤2,9%.

4122.text_preview:
O período mínimo de 
previsão da produtividade é de seis meses para o Sul de Minas Gerais e para o Cerrado Mineiro.

4123.text_preview:
Em anos de 
alta produtividade, os deficits hídricos afetam mais o estádio reprodutivo do café, enquanto, em anos de baixa 
produtividade, afetam mais os estádios vegetativos da cultura.

4124.text_preview: Termos de indexação: Coffea arabica, agrometeorologia, clima, previsão, modelo, balanço hídrico.

4125.text_preview:
Introduction
Brazil is the world’s largest coffee producer with 
45.563,2 thousand sacks per year (Amarasinghe 
et al., 2015; Acompanhamento…, 2017), and few 
studies have forecasted yields as functio

4126.text_preview:
Coffee 
production and bean quality are highly sensitive to 
changes in microclimatic parameters (Craparo et 
al., 2015), mainly those related to water availability.

4127.text_preview:
Water deficits [DEFs, the lack of evapotranspiration 
in relation to a maximum (potential) theoretical value] 
reduce crop yields (Khamssi et al., 2011) by affecting 
the plant vegetative growth (DaMa

4128.text_preview:
DEFs affect the amount of moisture extracted by 
roots, the spatial distribution of the root system, canopy 
size, and fruit growth of coffee plants (Amarasinghe et 
al., 2015).

4129.text_preview:
Reductions of coffee yields are mostly due to 
DEFs because the water stress after fertilisation affect 
fruit growth (Camargo, 2010).

4130.text_preview:
The effects of climate 
on crop yields can be evaluated with crop models 
(Shao et al., 2015).

4131.text_preview:
These models can help farmers to 
make decisions on achieving a sustainable agriculture 
(Syvertsen & Garcia-Sanchez, 2014).

4132.text_preview:
Models collect information from agrometeorology, 
remote sensing, plant physiology, plant science, soil 
science, and economics, in an interdisciplinary way to 
predict yields (Gouranga & Ashwani, 201

4133.text_preview:
The models 
can also assist on strategies of production by simulating 
the dynamics of crop growth (Wang et al., 2015).

4134.text_preview:
Several models have been published on coffee yield 
estimation.

4135.text_preview:
Santos & Camargo (2006) developed a 
This is an open-access article distributed under the 
Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License

bras., Brasília, v.53, n.12, p.1299-1310, Dec. 2018
DOI: 10.1590/S0100-204X2018001200002  
mathematical model to estimate yield losses of arabica 
coffee in the state of São Paulo.

4140.text_preview:
(2004) 
developed a model for estimating coffee yield in Minas 
Gerais, but the model was inconsistent, with highly 
discrepant estimate errors, highlighting the complexity 
of coffee modelling.

4141.text_preview: Studies of forecasting, however, are rare.

4142.text_preview:
Some 
studies have a probabilistic basis in the statistical 
models.

4143.text_preview:
Keong & Keng (2012) forecasted the yield 
of palm oil in Malaysia, nine months before the 
harvest, using multiple linear regression models and 
stepwise variable selection.

4144.text_preview:
Gouranga & Ashwani 
(2014) forecasted rice yields in India 30 days before 
the harvest.

4145.text_preview:
Finally, Moreto & Rolim (2015) forecasted 
the yield and quality of 'Valência' oranges six months 
before harvesting.

4146.text_preview:
No model, however, has yet been 
developed to forecast the yield of arabica coffee, in 
order to understand the influence of climate on the 
“bienniality” of coffee.

4147.text_preview:
Various authors have sought to understand the 
bienniality of coffee. The bienniality is the exhibition of 
coffee high and low yields in alternate years, which is 
commonly attributed to the restrict

4148.text_preview:
The photoassimilates in one 
year are allocated to the growth of branches, with little 
generation of productive germplasm. The photoassimilates 
of the next year are allocated to the germplasm, with

4149.text_preview:
The physiological cause of bienniality of coffee 
is complex (Valadares et al., 2013; Melke & Fetene, 
2014).

4150.text_preview:
When coffee develops plagiotropic branches, 
photoassimilates are allocated to this growth, 
promoting a large vegetative flux in the plant.

4151.text_preview:
This 
growth simultaneously promotes the multiplication of 
the number of buds that would mature for production 
only in the following year (Pereira et al., 2011).

4152.text_preview:
In 
the first year, coffee will thus show a high-vegetative 
growth and a low yield.

4153.text_preview:
In the following year, the 
crop will produce a high yield due to the high-bud 
formation in the previous year, but with low-vegetative 
growth (Melke & Fetene, 2014).

4154.text_preview:
Photoassimilates in 
years with high yields are allocated to bean filling, so 
vegetative growth is reduced, providing a lower yield 
again in the following year (Rodrigues et al., 2013).

4155.text_preview:
The maturity of plagiotropic branches is reached in 
three or four years in these regions.

4156.text_preview:
Estimation in science is the use of actual data to 
simulate an actual process, and forecasting is the use 
of actual data to simulate a future process or event.

4157.text_preview:
The 
forecast is the vanguard in the modelling of crops.

4158.text_preview:
Few 
papers have forecast coffee production to understand 
the influence of water deficit on the biennial coffee. The objective of this work was to develop 
agrometeorological models for the forecasti

4159.text_preview:
Materials and Methods
We used a historical series of climatic and 
phytotechnical data for coffee crops in the state of 
Minas Gerais, Brazil.

4160.text_preview:
The representative locations of 
coffee production used for modelling were Guaxupé 
(GXP), Monte Santo de Minas (MSM), and São 
Sebastião do Paraíso (SSP) – in the southern region 
of the state (SOMG)

4161.text_preview:
These 
data are statistics of all analysed municipalities, and 
were provided by the Cooxupé (Cooperativa Regional 
de Cafeicultores em Guaxupé).

4162.text_preview:
The crops were not 
irrigated and were of adult age.

4163.text_preview:
Daily climatic data for these locations were obtained 
for 1997–2014 by Campbell CR21X automatic weather 
stations (Campbell Scientific Inc., Logan, Utah, USA), 
containing sensors for rainfall (TE525

4164.text_preview:
Daily rainfall data and 
minimum, average, and maximum temperatures were 
arranged on a monthly basis to calculate the potential 
evapotranspiration (PET), using the model proposed 
by Camargo (1971).

Thornthwaite (1948) for tropical regions (Camargo & 
Sentelhas, 1997): PET

4182.text_preview:
The coffee cycle begins with the development of the 
root system induced by dormancy of the aerial part of 
the plant.

4183.text_preview:
The development of the root system is intense 
during this period (Figure 2).

4184.text_preview:
Roots grow throughout 
the plant cycle, but the growth is intensified when 
water is abundant (Larcher, 2004).

4185.text_preview:
Water deficits in 
tropical climates usually occur in the winter seasons.

4186.text_preview:
The phenological cycle of Coffee arabica requires 
two years to be completed (Figure 2).

4187.text_preview:
The growing 
season occurs in the first year, and the reproduction 
occurs in the second year.

4188.text_preview:
Coffee phenological cycle 
starts with the development of root system.

4189.text_preview:
The root 
system grows during periods of DEF that typically 
occur between June and September, coinciding with 
the dormancy period (Maestri & Barros, 1975).

4190.text_preview:
DEF 
was defined by Thornthwaite & Mather (1955) as the 
lack of evapotranspiration relatively to a maximum 
(potential) theoretical value, and it is determined as  
DEF = PET - AET

small round structures called “pinheads” that begin 
to expand into beans from Novemb

4227.text_preview:
Results and Discussion
The DEFs were more intense in CEMG, ranging from 
269 to 613 mm per cycle. The cycle DEFs in SOMG varied 
from 108 to 466 mm per cycle.

4228.text_preview:
The yields were more 
sensitive to DEF in CEMG than in SOMG.

4229.text_preview:
The average 
sensitivities as functions of DEF, in SOMG and CEMG, 
were -0.010 and - 0.031 sacks ha-1 mm-1 of DEF per 
cycle, respectively (Figures 4 A and B).

4230.text_preview:
A sensitivity 
of -0.031 sacks ha-1 mm-1 of DEF per cycle of coffee, 
with an average yield of 45.00 sacks ha-1, represents a 
reduction of 3.10 sacks ha-1 for every 100 mm of cycle 
DEF.

4231.text_preview:
Assuming a DEF of zero during the cycle, an 
average yield in CEMG would be 51.24 sacks ha-1, which 
is 20% higher than in SOMG (Figure 4 C).

4232.text_preview:
These values 
are similar to those reported by Fernandes et al.

4233.text_preview:
(2012), 
who found that the yield of coffee was usually higher 
in CEMG than in SOMG.

4234.text_preview:
Efforts were made to remove the equations with 
collinear variables, during the variable selection in the 
models, in order to forecast coffee yield by applying 
the APC method.

4235.text_preview:
We tested 16, 830 equations for each 
location, and removed an average of 12, 950 equations 
with collinear variables, leaving only 3,880 viable 
equations (Figure 5 A).

4236.text_preview:
These viable equations were 
assessed for a low MAPE, a high R2adj, and p < 0.05 
(Figure 5 B).

4237.text_preview:
To synthesize the information of the effect of DEFs 
on coffee yield, we identified the monthly DEFs of 
higher frequency in the yield forecasts of the 20 
top designs for each location (Figure 6 A an

A 
monthly DEF can be positively or negatively correlated

4246.text_preview:
DEFs in years of high yield (Figure 6 A) had more 
influence on flowering, bean formation, and yield 
during the phenological year (y).

4247.text_preview:
The monthly DEF 
mostly influenced the phases of vegetative development 
and final maturation in years of low yield (Figure 6 B); 
this result is in accordance with that by Pereira et al.

4248.text_preview:
(2011), who asserted that the growth of reproductive 
branches was the priority of development of coffee in 
years with low yield.

4249.text_preview:
DEFs in years of high yield had more influence 
during the production year (y), with higher frequencies 
in the models from April to July.

4250.text_preview:
The DEF in April of the 
second chronological year (DEFapr(i-1)), in high‑yield 
season, was the most influential DEF (Figure 6 A).

4251.text_preview:
DEFjul(i-1) occurred at the end of the growing period, 
and had a smaller influence on coffee yield.

4252.text_preview:
DEFsep(i-1) and DEFoct(i-1) showed great influence 
both in high- and low-yield seasons.

4253.text_preview:
DEFsep(i-1) was 
very influential in the cultivation, negatively affecting 
coffee high yield (Figure 6 A).

4254.text_preview:
This stage is at the end 
of the dormancy – when water restriction is desirable 
(Amarasinghe et al., 2015) – together with strong and 
uniform flowering (Ronchi et al., 2015).

4255.text_preview:
DEFoct(i-1), 
month of flowering, was negatively correlated with 
yield in the municipalities GXP, SSP, SDS, and TRS 
(Figure 6), evidencing that DEF in the coffee flowering 
period is not desirable.

4256.text_preview:
The agrometeorological models were developed 
by associating coffee yield with monthly DEFs.

4257.text_preview:
The 
models were calibrated and tested for years with 
high- (Figure 7) and low-yield seasons (Figure 8), to 
understand the limiting factors and to incorporate 
the bienniality of coffee production.

4258.text_preview:
The adjusted 
angular coefficients indicated the sensitivity of yield 
in relation to the monthly DEF, during the two years of 
the phenological cycle, for each location.

The models developed for the years with high yields 
were accurate, with a minimum MAPE of 0.39% 
(calibration), and an average forecasting period of 
up to nine months. For instance, the model for th

Cajanus generates a good effect for shading and pruning is required to give an 
adequate shade for coffee.

4505.text_preview:
Regarding soil humidity, measurements where made with an irrometer at 15, 20 and 25 centimeters 
depth and the results show more humidity below Brachiaria and Cajanus.

4506.text_preview:
In plant development, plants below Brachiaria and Cajanus are in average 30% taller than witnessed (1.3 
meters against 1.0).

4507.text_preview:
They also had three times more coffee beans by plant (1500 beans by plant against 
500).

4508.text_preview:

temporary shade (Gandul) in coffee development.

months to structure a shade that benefits coffee.

4519.text_preview:
As a Fabacea it has the capacity to incorporate 
nitrogen in the soil that can be used by coffee.

4523.text_preview:
Description of expected outcome:  Increased plant resilience against drought and heat stress through 
less extreme soil temperatures.

Soil moisture is also conserved in the dry seasons since the grass is

4525.text_preview:

effects, short and long term is still underway.

those wishing to try this, should do so on small plots only and study the outcome closely.

4527.text_preview:

What this manual does
u
u It introduces the c&c approach to climate 
change adaptation for t

u

to implement the c&c approach at a local 
or regional level, in cooperation with cof-
fee farmers and their communities.

4761.text_preview:
u
u It provides clear definitions of basic concepts, 
examples of climate change issues and risk 
management for coffee production, as well 
as guiding questions for further reflection. u
u It provi

4762.text_preview:
In doing so, the manual also supports 
users in building their knowledge and skills.

4763.text_preview:
u
u It serves as an important document for 
stakeholders who are looking to introduce 
climate change adaptation practices as 
part of their support for coffee farmers. What this manual does not do
u

4764.text_preview:
In this manual, 
c&c deliberately does not instruct on what 
to implement or how to measure x or y for a 
specific adaptation option.

4765.text_preview:
Instead, coffee far-
mers and service providers should use the ma-
nual as a guide for developing the adaptation 
options that apply to their particular context.

4766.text_preview:
They should not depend on the manual as the 
only approach to climate change adaptation, 
but rather as a helpful tool in their journey to 
making coffee production systems more resi-
lient and to bui

4767.text_preview:
There is no one-size-fits-all solution to 
climate change, as it always is a location-spe-
cific phenomenon and entails uncertainty 
of future risks.

4768.text_preview:
Therefore, climate change 
adaption needs to be a continuous process.

4769.text_preview:
The overall objective of the initiative for coffee & climate (c&c) is to support coffee farmers in building 
their resilience to climate change.

4770.text_preview:
A key output of the initiative is the c&c approach, a five-step process 
that introduces climate change adaptation at the farm level and supports actors in putting theory into 
practice.

4771.text_preview:
This systematic and participatory approach is primarily designed to assist extension services 
and rural development programs in supporting farmers in their adaptation to changing climatic condi-
tion

4772.text_preview:
This manual is a step-by-step guide for implementing the c&c approach, focusing specifically on the 
adaptation of coffee production in response to climate change at the farm level.

4773.text_preview:
It has been developed 
on the basis of experiences and lessons learned during the c&c pilot projects.

4774.text_preview:
Introduction
 
Target group
u

working on sustainability aspects with coffee 
farmers in the field, including governmental 
extension services, NGOs,

4775.text_preview:
It is highly 
relevant to those looking to develop a climate 
risk management program in order to deal with 
the adverse impacts of climate change, and to 
reduce potential harms or associated losses.

4776.text_preview:
Guidance
This manual is divided into two main sections: 
u
u Section 1 provides a general introduction  
to the effects of climate change on the 
coffee sector, and presents the c&c toolbox 
as well

Section 1  |  The essentials of the c&c approach
7
Global rainfall is increasing because war-
mer air holds more moisture.

4780.text_preview:
However, this 
does not mean that all regions will receive 
more rain, but rather that when it does rain, 
it might just rain harder.

4781.text_preview:
This means that soil 
erosion and landslides are likely to increase.

4782.text_preview:
The world is experiencing more extreme  
weather, with areas becoming hotter, wetter,  
drier or even cooler.

4783.text_preview:
This is difficult to prove  
statistically, but data from scientific studies 
and the insurance industry show an increa-
sing frequency of severe weather events.

4784.text_preview:
This means coffee farmers may experience 
more extreme weather, both hot and cold.

4786.text_preview:
The world’s average 
temperature is rising, especially the minimum 
temperatures.

4787.text_preview:
Since the rate of change is quite 
slow, any differences may be virtually undetecta-
ble, even to farmers.

4788.text_preview:
Pests and diseases, however, 
may grow much quicker when a certain threshold 
(often unknown or difficult to measure) is crossed.

4789.text_preview:
The rate of global warming is uneven due to  
the effect of the oceans, which absorb about 
92% of the sun’s energy and then move it 
around through horizontal and vertical currents.

4790.text_preview:
There may still be many years in which average 
ambient temperatures do not rise significant-
ly.

4791.text_preview:
Parts of the world may even experience 
cooler seasons, as seasonal winds shift and 
cause warming in another part of the world.

4792.text_preview:
1  |  Climate change in the coffee sector
Climate change has become an internationally recognized problem.

4793.text_preview:
Its impacts have been acknowled-
ged on a global scale, in a range of different sectors – agriculture being one of them.

4794.text_preview:
The main effects 
on agricultural production are expected to be increased variability, a decrease of production in certain 
areas and changes in geography.

4795.text_preview:
The global causes and effects of climate change have become very well known and will be briefly  
covered here.

4796.text_preview: For more in-depth information on this topic, please consult separate reviews1.

4798.text_preview:
General facts about global climate change

8
Climate Change Adaptation in Coffee Production
Glossary of climate-related terms 2
Weather: Describes atmospheric conditions 
at a particular place in ter

4799.text_preview:
Climate: Is often defined as the weather  
averaged over a long period of time (normally 
30 years).

4800.text_preview:
Global warming: Increase in average global 
temperature.

4801.text_preview:
Climate change: Any significant change in  
climate, such as temperature or precipitati-
on, that lasts for an extended period of time, 
typically decades, whether due to natural 
variability or human

4802.text_preview:
Climate variability: Refers to variations in the 
current state of the climate, e.g.

4803.text_preview:
the amount of 
rainfall received from year to year; also inclu-
des extended droughts, floods, and conditions 
that result from periodic El Niño and La Niña 
events (ENSO).

4804.text_preview:
Regional or local warming: Can be caused by 
a change in land use and can exacerbate local 
climate conditions and extremes.

4805.text_preview:
Climate hazards: The potentially damaging 
hydro-meteorological events or phenomena, 
such as increasing temperatures or changes 
in rainfall patterns, as well as the intensity 
and frequency of extre

4806.text_preview:
Climate impact: The effects of climate change 
in natural or human systems.

4807.text_preview: What does this mean for farmers?

4808.text_preview:
Farmers are experiencing increasingly extreme 
and unpredictable weather and climate patterns.

4809.text_preview:
They can no longer expect the favorable condi-
tions that a perennial crop like coffee needs for 
consecutive harvests.

4810.text_preview:
This has major implications 
on their livelihoods and strategies – should they 
invest more to adapt or to diversify?

4811.text_preview:
There are equally serious implications for farmer 
support structures.

4812.text_preview:
The high levels of uncertainty 
make it difficult to give accurate advice on how 
to prioritize scarce resources to reduce vulne-
rability.

4813.text_preview:
The purpose of the c&c initiative is to 
assist support services by developing and testing 
techniques and tools in order to evaluate the most 
pressing risks of climate change and make it easier 
to

4814.text_preview:
The effects of weather and climate (see glossary 
below) on coffee operate on a range of timescales: 
u
u Short-term events, such as tropical storms
u
u Mid-term events, such as El Niño and other os-

4815.text_preview:
In many 
cases, a lack of good climatic data from mete-
orological stations makes it difficult to under-
stand how the climate is changing.

4816.text_preview:
An important 
aspect of the c&c approach is to enable informed 
judgments about the risks of climate change for 
different local contexts.

4818.text_preview:
These potentially damaging hydro- 
meteorological events or phenomena are called 
climate hazards3.

4819.text_preview:
The effects of climate change in natural or human 
systems are called climate impacts.

4820.text_preview:
These effects 
can be direct (on the coffee tree) or indirect.

4821.text_preview:
Some potential negative climate impacts on  
Arabica varieties, which are particularly sensitive 
to climate extremes, are listed in Table 1 below.

4822.text_preview:
Coffee production is highly dependent on  
a regular sequence of weather events.

4823.text_preview:
Ideal 
climate conditions for Arabica coffee are:
u
u A dry period of three months to stress trees 
in order for them to flower well, but not too

Farmers usually experience these as a

ture practices”, which includes any practices, stra-
tegies or measures taken in response to climate

However, c&c also aims to develop tools

4827.text_preview:
Robusta is also affected by climate extremes, 
though it can tolerate higher temperatures and is 
more resistant to some pests and diseases.

4828.text_preview:
This 
may be one reason why the percentage of global 
coffee production of Robusta has risen from 20 to 
40% since 1980.

4829.text_preview:
Robusta does however require 
heavier rainfall, which, because of the increased 
likelihood of prolonged droughts, means that 
irrigation is likely to become an increasingly 
essential requirement.

4830.text_preview:
Extreme weather events over the past few years 
(e.g.

4831.text_preview:
heavy rainfall between 2009-2011 in Colombia 
or a drought period in 2014 in Minas Gerais, Brazil) 
demonstrate that there can be a substantial impact 
on revenues and, therefore, on the livelihoods o

4832.text_preview:
It is possible that such events could have 
occurred without climate change, but it is also very 
likely that they have been made worse by it.

4833.text_preview:
The overall result of the negative impacts of ext-
reme weather conditions is a reduction in coffee 
quantity and quality, and increasing production 
costs due to the need for additional inputs or lab

4835.text_preview:
Coffee production is also 
very intricate and varies greatly from country 
to country.

4836.text_preview:
However, the adopted production 
system within each region is often quite static, 
with only moderate changes over time.

4837.text_preview:
This 
means that coffee producers will require major 
investments of time and funds if they are to 
cope with the challenges of climate change.

4838.text_preview:
The current state of knowledge on coffee and cli-
mate change suggests that supporters will need 
to consider more drastic changes in  
the future.

4839.text_preview:
It seems inevitable that:
1)	 Some traditional coffee production zones 
will no longer be suitable for growing  
coffee, creating a need to find crop diversi-
fication and substitution solutions.

4840.text_preview:
This is 
already happening at the lower margins of 
coffee production in many countries, but is 
mostly poorly researched and supported.

4841.text_preview:
Definition: Climate change adaptation
Adjustment in natural or human systems in response to 
actual or expected climatic stimuli (climate hazards) or 
their effects, which moderates harm or exploits b

4842.text_preview:
3)	 A few zones may gain climatic suitability  
for coffee production.

4843.text_preview:
This manual deals with point 2) only; points 1) 
and 3) should also be considered and planned 
if they are to happen in a way that maximizes 
sustainability and minimizes damage to com-
munities and t

4844.text_preview:
Therefore, the 
systematic approach to adaptation that is pre-
sented here should be seen as just one element 
in a comprehensive climate change strategy, 
which goes beyond coffee production alone. C

4845.text_preview:
Adopted from Fellmann, T. 2012
Climate change impacts are experienced locally, 
which means adaptation responses also have to 
be defined on a site or regionally specific level.

4846.text_preview:
Effective adaptation to climate change must be 
based on a thorough understanding of the vulne-
rability (or susceptibility) of the targeted coffee 
agro-ecosystem and coffee farmer communities. The i

4847.text_preview:
A ‘system’ does not simply refer to a 
farm level system of production, but also to far-
ming communities, the broader landscape and the 
whole supply chain, including road infrastructure, 
storage fa

4848.text_preview:
Therefore, adaptation strategies might focus on 
increasing the resilience of groups of people as 
well as the resilience of the agricultural systems 
that their livelihoods rely on.

4849.text_preview:
The vulnerability 
of both coffee agro-ecosystems and communities 
are, therefore, important factors when conside-
ring the effects of climate change.

4850.text_preview:
Vulnerability can be defined as susceptibility to 
harm5.

4851.text_preview:
Often it is depicted as the result of a num-
ber of factors (Figure 2) and can therefore be a dif-
ficult concept to use or define.

4852.text_preview:
The various terms 
are best explained by the use of an example:
1.3	 How can we respond to climate change?

4853.text_preview: What is climate vulnerability and adaptive capacity?

4854.text_preview:
Guidance: Adaptive capacity
u
u Adaptive capacity can be enhanced by 
increasing the resources and knowledge 
of farmers and by supporting indivi-
duals and organizations in responding 
appropriately

4855.text_preview:
u
u Adaptive capacity can be enhanced 
by concrete adaptation options, e.g.

4856.text_preview:
by training farmers on how to develop 
more effective irrigation and how to 
construct water storage systems, or in-
directly by improving access to finance 
through low-rate loans.

Therefore, the purpose of this manual is to assist 
in the increasing adaptive capacity of farmers 
and those who are helping them.

4860.text_preview:
Adaptation options are concrete measures focu-
sed on reducing climate vulnerability and climate 
risk.

4861.text_preview:
Table 2 shows some examples of how coffee 
producers can respond to climate hazards previ-
ously listed in Table 1, and reduce climate risks 
by implementing adaptation options.

4862.text_preview:
Adaptation 
options may also include measures that respond 
A farmer may perceive that the coffee farm has an 
increasing exposure to coffee leaf rust (Hemileia 
vastatrix) because of a changing clima

4863.text_preview:
The coffee 
variety (Coffea Arabica) may be susceptible to 
the disease and hence has a high sensitivity.

4864.text_preview:
The 
farmer can do little to reduce exposure to the pro-
blem and instead chooses to reduce sensitivity by 
either applying fungicide regularly or by planting 
a new rust-resistant variety.

4865.text_preview:
The correct choice is 
not easy and will vary according to circumstance.

4866.text_preview:
If the farmer receives expert advice, increases 
knowledge and has sufficient funding with which 
to make a decision, he can be said to have a good 
adaptive capacity.

4867.text_preview:
Therefore, even though the 
likelihood of disease attacks continues to rise, the 
farmer can balance this by reducing vulnerability.

4868.text_preview:
As seen in Figure 2, the climate vulnerability 
of a production system is a combination of the 
potential impacts caused by exposure and sensi-
tivity to climate change, as well as the adaptive 
capac

4869.text_preview:
These factors together imply that 
the impact of climate in the field is a result of the 
relationship between hazard frequency and se-

Note
A system is vulnerable if it is exposed 
and sen

4870.text_preview:
In contrast, a 
system is less vulnerable or more resili-
ent if it is less exposed, less sensitive or 
has a strong adaptive capacity.

ween communities, governments or businesses)  
as well as flexible processes to support lear-

4873.text_preview:
How to think about adaptation
Often climate adaptation is talked about as a way 
of reducing vulnerability.

4874.text_preview:
While this can be useful, 
the c&c approach prefers to think of it in terms 
of increasing resilience and building adaptive 
capacity.

4875.text_preview:
This approach is more positive and may 
be easier to engage stakeholders by discussing 
opportunities to increase their resilience, rather 
than viewing them as victims of climate change.

4876.text_preview:
The message should be that adaptation helps 
farmers to be more successful coffee producers.

4877.text_preview: indirectly to a given climate hazard.

4878.text_preview:
For example, 
an indirect measure could be providing training to 
a community on how to develop off-farm liveli-
hood activities.

4879.text_preview:
It is also important to note that the development 
of adaptive capacity is not simply a case of being 
able to recover from climate events in the short 
term.

4880.text_preview:
It is also about providing communities and 
individuals with the ability to adapt to changes 
in the environment and the possible social and 
economic consequences of these changes in the 
long term.

4881.text_preview:
Resilience
In recent years, resilience has become a heavily 
used term and, like ‘sustainability’, has been used 
in many ways and contexts.

4882.text_preview:
For the purposes 
of this manual, resilience means the ability to 
respond effectively to climate change impacts, 
while still continuing to function at a satisfactory 
level.

4883.text_preview:
A useful definition for resilience for a coffee 
production system includes the following: 7
1.

4884.text_preview:
The amount of disruption that coffee pro-
ducers can withstand while still remaining 
unchanged (the capacity to absorb change); 
2.

4885.text_preview:
How much coffee producers can adapt what 
they do in response to a changing climate  
(the capacity to adapt to change); 
3. The capacity of coffee producers to learn 
about what needs to be changed

Terms and definitions in reference to climate change adaptation 
Risk: The probability of harmful consequences 
or expected losses (e.g.

4892.text_preview:
death, injury, loss of 
livelihoods, reduced economic productivity, 
and/or environmental damage) resulting from 
interactions between climate hazards, expo-
sure to these hazards and vulnerable condi

4893.text_preview:
Risk can be thought of as the interac-
tion of hazard and vulnerability as shown in 
Figure 2. It is sometimes expressed as: Risk = 
Hazard x Vulnerability.

4894.text_preview:
In practice though, it 
is often difficult to quantify these terms to be 
able to use this equation in the field.

4895.text_preview:
Exposure: The degree to which a system  
(e.g.

4896.text_preview:
a farm, production system or coffee 
plant) in a defined area is exposed to signi-
ficant variations in conditions (e.g.

4897.text_preview:
a coffee 
plant that is exposed to high humidity).

4898.text_preview:
This is more difficult to control, but could 
be altered by reducing shade in some cir-
cumstances, though this would increase 
exposure to other weather variables.

4899.text_preview:
Sensitivity: The level of tolerance in a system 
(e.g.

4900.text_preview:
a farm, production system or coffee plant) 
to climate variability or change.

4901.text_preview:
For example, 
a coffee plant that gets rust is highly sensiti-
ve to increased minimum temperatures and 
rainfall frequency at key points in its cycle.

4902.text_preview:
Planting a variety of plant that is less suscep-
tible to rust infection can reduce sensitivity.

4903.text_preview:
Vulnerability: The degree to which a sys-
tem is susceptible to, or unable to cope 
with, adverse effects of climate change, 
including climate variability and extremes.

4904.text_preview:
In coffee production, susceptibility to cli-
mate change can be increased by old tree 
stock, poor soils, poor knowledge, etc.

4905.text_preview:
8	
Adapted from United Nations International Strategy 
for Disaster Reduction [UNISDR], 2009
Adaptive capacity: The ability of a system to 
adjust to climate variability and extremes, to 
take advant

4906.text_preview:
For example, coffee far-
mers with high adaptive capacity may be bet-
ter able to adjust their farming practices to suit 
drought conditions than those with low capaci-
ty.

4907.text_preview:
Adaptive capacity includes the practical 
knowledge, experience, resources and social 
networks of coffee farmers and extensionists.

4908.text_preview:
Resilience: The ability of a system to resist,  
rebound or recover from the effects of a clima-
te hazard.

4909.text_preview:
A resilient community of coffee far-
mers would be well-placed to manage hazards, 
to minimise their effects and/or to recover 
quickly from any negative impacts, resulting in 
a similar or improved s

4910.text_preview:
There are strong lin-
kages between resilience and adaptive capaci-
ty; consequently, resilience also varies greatly 
for different groups within a community.

4911.text_preview:
Maladaptation: An action that may appear to  
be adaptive, but might actually turn out to 
be counterproductive.

4912.text_preview:
For example, coffee 
farmers in marginal conditions (e.g.

4913.text_preview:
very high 
temperatures or frequent droughts) may strive 
to adapt their coffee production methods, but 
might actually be helped best by developing 
diversification options because ambient tem-
perat

5063.text_preview:
During a field visit, consider that farmers may have already introduced innovative or adapted 
farming practices as a result of changing climatic conditions.

5064.text_preview:
Make sure to observe these,  
as they may be applicable for others in the region, too.

5065.text_preview: Remember also that not all observations are necessarily signs of climate change impacts.

5066.text_preview: For example, erosion could be partially the result of deforestation on a hillside.

5067.text_preview:
Similarly,  
it is impossible to identify a single wind damage event as being the result of manmade  
climate change.

5068.text_preview:
This is why the triangulation of evidence is so important (see Step 2), as it 
will help you establish a clearer picture of climate change impacts.

your community and ensure they are well

5071.text_preview:

climate change as a starting point for 
actions taken in anticipation of risks and 
opportunities associated with longer-term 
climate change.

5072.text_preview:
u
u Use adaptive management to cope with 
uncertainty and recognize the value of a 
phased approach to cope with uncertainty.

5073.text_preview:
u
u Recognize the value of no/low regrets  
and win-win adaptation options (options 
that yield additional benefits or yield 
benefits even in the absence of a climate 
impact) in terms of cost-effec

u
u Avoid actions that limit future adapta-
tions or restrict adaptive actions of others.

5075.text_preview:
u

approach that also includes monitoring  
and re-evaluations of risks.

about the process and its objectives, and assess

See “Guidance: Principles of good adaptation” for

5084.text_preview:
Many organizations spend very little time on 
scoping.

5085.text_preview:
They see adaptation as a technical issue 
that can be tackled on a project level as a distinct 
task to be done either in-house or by external 
consultants.

5086.text_preview: Unfortunately, this approach is often insufficient.

Although the assessment of impacts is a fairly ob-
jective process, decisions about adaptation still 
need to be based on policy setting for ‘desired 
outcomes’ (what are we adapting for?)

5088.text_preview:
in additi-
on to ‘objective’ threats and opportunities (what 
are we adapting to?).

5089.text_preview:
Many parts of the process 
are subjective.

You will be required to consider 
what matters to you and to the farmers you work 
with, and to prioritize actions.

Throughout Steps 1 to 3, it will be important

5092.text_preview:
Stakehol-
ders (especially smallholder farmers) will play a

Decision-making for ad-

understood and recorded.

on how to do this in Step 3.

5108.text_preview: Step 2 is the core step of the c&c approach.

5109.text_preview:
It is in 
this step that you will learn about climate change 
and assess the current climatic risks and impacts 
on-site.

5110.text_preview:
It requires you to combine scientific 
evidence with local experience and know-how to 
form a deeper understanding about climate-re-
lated impacts and adaptation needs.

5111.text_preview:
In this step, 
coffee farmers and stakeholders embark on a 
participatory process to explore and learn about 
climate change adaptation and its relation to exis-
ting farming practices.

5112.text_preview:
This builds on the initial 
understanding that was established in Step 1.

u

production, coffee farmers and their families 
in a specific area?

5114.text_preview:
u

production systems more resilient?

5171.text_preview:
Collect information from farmers
Coffee farmers are a primary source of informa-
tion, as they are familiar with existing farming 
conditions, and often notice any changes in 
production as they occur

5172.text_preview:
Information from farmers and farming communi-
ties is crucial to identifying climate-related risks 
and prioritizing appropriate adaptation measu-
res.

5173.text_preview:
To analyze the impacts of climate change on 
coffee production from a farmer’s perspective, 
combine the following three methods:  
u
u One-on-one farmer interviews  
(individual farmer diagnostics)

5174.text_preview:
sensitization work-
shops on climate change and impact on coffee 
production or Climate Witness Workshops
I.

5175.text_preview:
Individual farmer diagnostics
A farmer diagnostic is based on individual farmer 
interviews and field visits.

5176.text_preview:
It will help you to: a) 
identify climate change impacts on coffee pro-
duction and b) capture the perceptions, expe-
riences and observations of individual farmers 
with regard to current production

5177.text_preview:
Visit individual farmers, interview them and take 
a short visit to their farm.

5178.text_preview:
During the interview 
identify the three most pressing problems and, 
during the visual inspection of the farm, observe 
the general state of the production plot.

5179.text_preview:
During 
this initial questioning, it is best not to mention 
climate or climate change, so that the farmer 
is not prompted to comment on it.

5180.text_preview:
If climate 
problems do not feature in their responses, this 
may indicate that climate change impacts are not 
important or that there are other more pressing 
concerns, such as coffee prices.

5181.text_preview:
Also, it may be the 
case that some problems identified are related 
to climate, but are not seen as such by the farmer 
(e.g.

5182.text_preview: increasing numbers of pests or diseases).

5183.text_preview:
It is important to define the number of farmers 
you will interview to get an appropriate sample.

5184.text_preview:
This will depend on the size of the area that your 
project or extension service covers, as well as the 
climatic, environmental and socio-cultural diver-
sity of the working area.

5185.text_preview:
Try also to include far-
mers located in marginal coffee production areas, 
as they may provide highly relevant information, 
not only about current climate impacts, but also 
about future risks for t

5186.text_preview:
Key questions for the farmer interview: 
u
u What are the main challenges you face in 
coffee production?

5187.text_preview:
u
u What other challenges do you face in  
production?

5188.text_preview:
u
u If climate has not been mentioned previously by 
the farmer, ask the following:Have you noticed 
any changes in weather over the time you have 
been farming?

5189.text_preview:
For reference, it might be useful 
to ask for changes in the past 20-30 years.

5190.text_preview:
After collecting this information in the field, data 
must be structured and analyzed.

5191.text_preview:
For example, 
you could rank the problems expressed by farmers 
in order of frequency (see “Learning from experi-
ence: Ranking problems expressed by farmers”).

5192.text_preview:
This exercise will help you to prioritize the most 
relevant climate hazards and impacts on coffee 
production, which will allow you to later focus on 
the specifics of each possible adaptation option

5193.text_preview:
The 
definition of coffee farmers used here incor-
porates all growers of coffee, regardless of 
their age, gender or the size of their land.

5194.text_preview:
Climate Change Adaptation in Coffee Production
36
Step 2
In a farm-to-farm survey in Mbeya Rural Igale, Tan-
zania, 20 farmers were visited in 14 villages by c&c 
project staff.

5195.text_preview:
In these interviews, the farmers provided a wide 
range of problems, which were then ordered in a 
list using a system of ranking.

5196.text_preview:
Since not all farmers 
prioritize the same challenges, a list of identified 
problems will usually contain more than three.

5197.text_preview:
Three points were given for the first problem, two for 
second and one for third.

5198.text_preview:
The result was a well-or-
dered list of the main climate-related problems ex-
pressed by farmers.

5199.text_preview:
Disease, and specifically Coffee 
Berry Disease (CBD,) was the most prominent issue, 
with climate coming third and the need for irrigation 
fourth.

5200.text_preview:
Finance was identified as the second most 
important problem, but is not directly related to 
climate.

5201.text_preview:
A wide range of production issues were identified 
through farm visits, which indicated a lack of good 
agricultural practice.

5202.text_preview:
It was, therefore, quite under-
standable that climate did not receive a higher rank.

5203.text_preview:
The top priority was funding, which is necessary to 
improve coffee management.

5207.text_preview:
Be 
as specific as possible when characterizing the 
frequency and intensity of climate hazards and, 
where possible, distinguish the cause(s) from the 
consequence(s).

5208.text_preview:
It is important to remember that 
climate impacts do not occur in isolation from so-
cial, economic and other environmental changes.

5209.text_preview:
Therefore, it is not always easy or useful to try to 
isolate problems and define them as “purely cli-
mate-related”.

5210.text_preview:
For example, climate changes may 
create more favorable conditions for a disease, 
but the disease may spread as a result of increa-
sed movement between farms.

5212.text_preview:
Farmer focus group discussions
A focus group discussion with coffee farmers who 
have a long history in the area (e.g.

5213.text_preview:
20-30 years) 
can be very helpful in collecting local percep-
tions and observations about climate hazards and 
impacts.

5214.text_preview:
Ask the farmers to answer these  
fundamental questions:
u
u How has the climate changed over the past 20 
years?

5215.text_preview:
Have you noticed any changes in rain-
fall or temperatures in specific months?

5216.text_preview:
u
u Have there been any changes in your farm’s 
production cycles?

5217.text_preview:
u
u What are the main climate or weather-related 
hazards?

5218.text_preview:
Do these hazards have secondary 
impacts?

5219.text_preview:
For example, heavy rain may lead to 
landslides that block roads and make market 
access difficult.

5220.text_preview:
u
u How are men and women (young and old) 
affected by climate hazards?

5221.text_preview:
u
u How do you view the future of coffee farming 
a) in your local area and b) in your region?

The two-way vision enriches discussions on how 
farmers perceive climate change, how these chan-

5241.text_preview:
The priority values exercise helps farmers deter-
mine which values are of great importance to them 
and should be maintained in the future.

5242.text_preview:

activity, ‘values’ are considered as environmental 
assets, such as soil, water, a specific plant, a speci-
fic crop, etc.

5243.text_preview:
The list of problems helps to assess climate chan-

Finding, interpreting and making practical use

5290.text_preview:
Past and present climate
An important step in gathering scientific informa-
tion is to access meteorological data and, if pos-
sible, to approach any local meteorological institu-
tes.

5291.text_preview:
Local research institutions or coffee umbrella 
organizations may also have relevant data.

5292.text_preview:
Scientific data can include past meteorological 
records, climate models for the region or spe-
cific studies.

5293.text_preview:
However, many people encounter 
difficulties when analyzing this information.

5294.text_preview:
In some places, the meteorological record is 
incomplete or inaccurate.

5295.text_preview:
Even when data are 
available, this information is rarely presented 
in a form that is easy to understand.

5296.text_preview:
Meteorological data may be available only as 
monthly maximums and minimums of tempe-
rature and rainfall.

5297.text_preview:
Specific data that are of 
interest to coffee, e.g.

5298.text_preview:
timing of the first rains, 
exact length of the dry season or extremes of 
temperatures, may often not be available.

5299.text_preview:
This 
creates a tendency to rely on projections in cli-
mate models, but it is important to remember 
that these present a range of future possibili-
ties rather than real predictions.

5300.text_preview:
Learning from experience
Difficulties in scientific data analysis
It should also be noted that uncertainty is 
inherent to climate projections; no one knows 
for sure which of these future possibiliti

5301.text_preview:
However, attempts have 
been made to determine not only possibilities, 
but also probabilities.

5302.text_preview:
The latter are often sub-
jective, e.g.

5303.text_preview:
an estimate based on the available 
information and evidence.

5304.text_preview:
For example, scien-
tists may weigh future projections according 
to how well they represent the past climate.

5305.text_preview:
When using projections, you must always 
remember that these are not rigid predictions 
on which to base precise decisions, but rather 
a means of understanding the range of impacts 
that are possible

5306.text_preview:
Meteorological data are often presented as a set of 
averages, but for the purposes of farming, it is ac-
tually more important to have the extreme values 
(e.g.

5308.text_preview:
That 
said, some countries have daily records available, 
which allows for more analyses of raw data by 
those with corresponding skills and experience.

5309.text_preview:
For 
example, by interpreting meteorological informa-
tion and putting it into a specific format, such as 
climate maps or climate models, such information 
can easily be presented to outside audience

Step 2
Different models tend to agree on some changes 
more than others.

5311.text_preview:
For example, virtually all mo-
dels predict an increase in temperature, but they 
often have conflicting predictions for the rate of 
this increase.

5312.text_preview:
There are also generally great diffe-
rences in predictions of rainfall.

5313.text_preview:
In order to show 
these differences and uncertainties, models will 
often present a range of possible future outco-
mes.

5314.text_preview:
For example, a projected 3°C temperature 
increase by 2050 may come with an uncertainty 
range of 1.5°C to 5°C; average rainfall projections 
for a region may be negative, but the uncertain-
ty range

5315.text_preview:
Projections for 
extreme weather events are usually even more 
uncertain13.

5316.text_preview:
Climate projections are often only available at the 
regional or national level, and may not provide 
the specific detail required at the local level.

5317.text_preview:
However, if used correctly, they can still be a 
valuable source of information for future trends in 
a given area.

5318.text_preview:
At the very least, they can be used to 
visualize climate change and can thus support in 
creating awareness among stakeholders.

5319.text_preview:
A lack of scientific data 
Unfortunately, in many coffee-producing coun-
tries, good meteorological data can be scarce and 
research stations few; historical data can often be 
incomplete – especially

5320.text_preview:
If that is 
the case, consult local historians, anthropologists 
and other experts, either professional or amateur, 
in addition to consulting the Internet.

5321.text_preview:
u

often has a long and rich history.

Reports  
from research stations and commodity boards 
It is important to look for extreme temperature 
values and determine if they are becoming either 
more extreme or more frequent.

5323.text_preview:
In addition, make 
sure to look at the timing and intensity of rainfall.

5324.text_preview:
Although there may be no indication of changes 
in annual rainfall, there could be signs of more 
intermittent rainfall or changes in the onset or 
end of the rainy season.

5325.text_preview:
Where possible, seek the 
assistance of a meteorologist.

5326.text_preview:
Keep in mind that other organizations may have 
already conducted similar research.

5327.text_preview:
Therefore, it 
is also helpful to consult government officials and 
research organizations or NGOs in your region.

Learning from experience

dry material is a fire hazard during the drought 
season, as it could cause a bush fire.

5456.text_preview:
For these 
farms, mulch could be a maladaptation.

A unique feature of coffee is that it is grown 
in a wide range of conditions.

Therefore, 
when working with coffee farmers, adaptati-
on options must be chosen according to the 
particular coffee system, rather than adap-

5467.text_preview:
The development of a c&c project pathway can be 
very helpful during the design, implementation 
and M&E stages of adaptation.

5468.text_preview:
This approach is 
more widely known as a ‘theory of change’ and is 
both a planning tool and a key point of reference 
for M&E16.

5469.text_preview:
A project pathway is an explanation of how a 
group of stakeholders expect to reach a common-
ly shared goal.

5470.text_preview:
It helps set out the logic behind an 
implementation process, connecting activities to 
outcomes and articulating the assumptions that 
underpin decisions.

5471.text_preview:
These assumptions explain 
the logical connections between early, intermedi-
ate and long-term outcomes and why the pro-
posed activities are expected to result in these 
outcomes.

5472.text_preview:
Using the hypothetical example of the 
Promotion of Resilience and Prevention of Rust 
(PRPR) Project in Guatemala, the main steps in de-
veloping a project pathway are described below.

5473.text_preview:
C
Develop a c&c project pathway
Resources
Extension staff for FFS
Funds for FFS materials 
Funds for nursery set-up
Funds for subsidizing seedling distribution
Indicators  
for on-farm 
effectiveness

5475.text_preview:
These can 
be ordered sequentially, like a pathway.

5476.text_preview:
Example: What are the changes that are required

5477.text_preview:
What are the 
conditions that need to be in place for change to 
happen?

5478.text_preview:
The illustration below provides a set of example 
preconditions at four different levels of the PRPR 
Project.

5479.text_preview:
The logic between the levels is apparent 
(e.g.

5480.text_preview:
level 4 can be achieved if level 3 is in place, 
level 3 is achieved if level 2 is in place and so 
on, working backwards from the project’s goal).

5481.text_preview:
Figure 17 shows that the full project pathway is 
comprised of a more complex set of outcomes and 
preconditions.

5482.text_preview:
I	
Define your primary outcome or goal
Just as you might plan a journey with a clear final 
destination in mind, your project pathway should 
start with a desired outcome or goal.

5483.text_preview:
Example: The long-term objective of the PRPR 
Project is that “coffee farmers are more resilient 
to coffee rust events and have greater capacity to 
adapt to climate change risks.” 
II 	 Identify th

5484.text_preview:
This 
requires thinking in backward steps, beginning 
Guidance
Precondition refers to a condition that must be fulfilled before other tasks can be fulfilled.

5485.text_preview: Outcome refers to the changes that result from implementation activities (e.g.

5486.text_preview:
increased 
knowledge of rust prevention measures could be an outcome).

5487.text_preview: In your project pathway, each outcome is a precondition for the next, e.g.

5488.text_preview:
the overall  
objective can be achieved if certain intermediate outcomes are achieved, these  
intermediate outcomes can be achieved if early stage outcomes are achieved and so on.

5490.text_preview:
The monitoring of progress is reliant on 
a selection of indicators that can accurately repre-
sent changes.

5491.text_preview:
Look at each outcome individually 
and consider how you might measure progress in 
achieving each of these.

5492.text_preview:
More detailed guidance 
on developing indicators can be found in the M&E 
section on page 79.

5493.text_preview:
Table 13 shows some examp-
le indicators for the PRPR Project.

5494.text_preview:
It is also possible to use more general indicators, 
such as household income or percentage of rust 
incidences in the region.

5495.text_preview:
While these indicators 
are useful, however, it is more difficult to attribute 
general indicators solely to the implementation 
of adaptation options, especially given the long 
timeframe associated

5496.text_preview:
For example, a record of no rust incidents recor-
ded for three years is not necessarily a result of 
adaptation measures that have been implemen-
ted.

5497.text_preview:
Similarly, if a rust outbreak does occur, it is 
not an automatic sign that the adaptation measu-
res have failed.

5498.text_preview:
In this case, it would perhaps be 
better to measure financial losses resulting from 
a rust outbreak relative to other communities that 
have not implemented adaptation options.

5499.text_preview:
V	 Construct the pathway
Once all steps have been completed, put them to-
gether into a single diagram.

5500.text_preview:
This does not have to 
be a work of art; a flipchart diagram as part of the 
planning process will suffice.

5501.text_preview:
Perhaps take a photo 
for future reference.

5502.text_preview:
Remember that the project 
pathway will need to be updated throughout the 
implementation of adaptation options.

5503.text_preview:
There may 
be clear points at which to do this, e.g.

5504.text_preview:
midway 
through the project or after a particular phase has 
been completed.

5505.text_preview:
III	  Identify assumptions 
It is inevitable that you will have made assump-
tions in your backwards mapping about how and 
why each level informs the next.

5506.text_preview:
Since the future 
is inherently uncertain, it is important to record 
these assumptions in order to check if they are still 
appropriate during the course of implementation.

5507.text_preview:
You may find it useful to think in terms of the cri-
teria for selecting adaptation options (see Step 3):
u
u Acceptability
u
u Feasibility
u
u Effectiveness
u
u Affordability/cost
u
u Timing/urgency

on a few 
farms or in a certain designated area) before

Step 4
u
u Training and visits provide opportunities for 
extension workers to train farmers in certain 
farming practices.

5551.text_preview:
Trainers then follow up 
to check whether these practices are being 
implemented appropriately, and support the 
producer with any additional technical advice 
that is required.

5552.text_preview:
Extension staff collect the 
producer’s observations and experiences, and 
report on any positive results or difficulties.

5553.text_preview:
u
u Demonstration plots (demo plots) show the 
ideal implementation of an adaptation option 
and its positive effects.

5554.text_preview:
u
u Exchange visits facilitate shared experiences 
and the exchange of knowledge between 
farmers.

5555.text_preview:
u
u Field days provide an opportunity to learn 
from ‘champion farmers’ who have experien-
ce in successfully implementing adaptation 
options.

5556.text_preview:
By meeting at his or her farm, other 
farmers learn by seeing good practice in a 
real-life context.

5557.text_preview: Additional information about the FFS is available in Section 2, Step 4 “Farmer Field Schools”.

5559.text_preview:
Farmer Field School
A Farmer Field School (FFS) consists of a group 
of farmers (15-25) who are interested in solving 
a specific production problem.

5560.text_preview:
It is conducted in 
a participatory manner that improves the ability 
of participants to identify problems and search 
for solutions through experimentation.

5561.text_preview:
Working 
together with extension workers, farmers design 
field experiments that compare potential adapta-
tion options to their existing farming practices.

5562.text_preview:
The objective is to help them understand 
agro-ecological processes and have them manage 
their production systems to yield the best results 
(see learning from experience example below).

5563.text_preview:
u
u  Observation, analysis and decision-making are 
key processes in an FFS.

5564.text_preview:
Farmers collect and 
analyze data in order to compare the perfor-
mance of crops under different management 
regimes, e.g.

5565.text_preview:
plant height, number of fruiting 
bodies, plant health, weed spectrum and den-
sity, disease and pest dynamics, soil moisture, 
yield and labor.

5566.text_preview:
An FFS goes beyond teaching, 
as it provides a forum where farmers and 
facilitators can exchange observations and 
experiences, as well as present new informa-
tion from outside the community.

5567.text_preview:
u
u A technically competent person is required to 
lead the group through hands-on exercises, and 
then step back once the group feels that they 
are able to work alone.

5568.text_preview:
This person can be an 
extension worker, a promoter farmer or an FFS 
graduate.

5569.text_preview:
FFS participants meet in their day-to-
day environments, e.g.

5570.text_preview:
in local schools, commu-
nity centers or on one of the participant’s farms.

5571.text_preview:

Test plots (trials) 
Before promoting a new or untested adaptation 
option through demo plots and FFS, it should 
be validated in the context in which it will be 
implemented.

5593.text_preview:
Through small-scale experiments, 
on-farm extension staff and farmers can obtain 
initial results on the feasibility and effectiveness 
of the proposed option.

5594.text_preview: The trial is usually made on a small scale, e.g.

5595.text_preview:
just a few trees and their surroundings, a small 
coffee nursery or a small infrastructure construc-
tion (e.g.

5597.text_preview:
For each trial, a work plan 
and measurement parameters must be in place.

5598.text_preview:
It is important to consider the capacity of the 
extension staff as well as the available resources 
in order to define parameters that are actually 
capable of being measured.

Keeping records of 
observations, specific data on activities, costs

5601.text_preview:
Early stages of promoting cover crops 
(Napier grass) as live mulch on test 
plots in Mbeya, Tanzania
Can Napier grass make coffee plots more resili-
ent to drought?

5602.text_preview: Is it acceptable to local farmers?

5603.text_preview:
In the Mbeya region, there is high competition 
between mulching materials for coffee fields 
and livestock.

5604.text_preview:
As a possible solution, Napier 
grass was promoted on test plots. The Napier 
grass was spread to cover the soil of the plot.

5605.text_preview:
It 
grows quickly, meaning it can also be used to 
feed livestock.

5606.text_preview:
Napier grass was planted as live 
mulch during the first season, but the impact 
on productivity still needs to be monitored.

5607.text_preview:
See also combining dry mulch and cover crops case study  
in the c&c toolbox.

5608.text_preview:
Learning from experience

Section 1 |  The essentials of the c&c approach
65
Step 4
The extent of drought season is a threat in Minas 
Gerais, Brazil.

5609.text_preview:
One adaptation option suggested 
by the c&c toolbox for increasing resistance to 
drought is the application of Gypsum.

5610.text_preview:
Gypsum 
draws soil nutrients lower into the soil profile.

5611.text_preview:
In 
response, the roots grow down, towards the nu-
trients and, in the process, the coffee plants can 
draw upon deeper and more humid soils, therefo-
re becoming more resistant to drought.

5612.text_preview:
The initial viability of the proposal was analyzed 
according to the availability of the input.

5613.text_preview:
In additi-
on, possible drawbacks were considered, such as 
specific soil types, especially sandy.

5614.text_preview:
Since Gypsum application was a relatively new 
technique in the local context, small-scale trials 
were established on-farm in order to prove effec-
tiveness, feasibility and cost benefits.

5615.text_preview:
A work plan for the test plot was developed and 
a technical proposal was defined in terms of 
amount and frequency of application.

5616.text_preview:
Test plot: Gypsum as a suitable adaptation option to drought
The procedure outlined in the work plan was  
as follows:  
u
u Select one or more fields to dig a 2m trench  
to study the soil profile.

5617.text_preview:
u
u Establish trial plots (20 x 20m) for Gypsum 
treatments.

5618.text_preview:
u
u Take soil samples for laboratory analysis  
and seek expert advice on interpretation.

5619.text_preview:
u
u Test different application rates, e.g.

5620.text_preview:
0, 7, 14, 21 
and 28 t/ha to look for cost-benefit relation.

5622.text_preview:
u
u Take soil samples up to 2m every six months 
and analyze for nutrient levels.

5623.text_preview:
u
u Keep records of yield measurements, soil  
analysis and general health and appearance  
of coffee trees throughout the two years.

5625.text_preview: For more detailed information see c&c toolbox.

When setting up a demo plot, it is important to

5628.text_preview:
Be sure to document activities, costs, farmer

5629.text_preview:
control of Coffee Berry Borer,

5630.text_preview:
Furthermore, sufficient resources are required to

5631.text_preview:
This mainly includes the
