5632.text_preview:
Subsidizing 
demo plots with external resources is a decision 
that must first be carefully analyzed, as it may put 
into question how replicable or sustainable the 
adaptation option is.

5634.text_preview:
Demonstration plots 
Extension staff will want farmers to adapt to cer-
tain farming practices that are likely to increase 
resilience to specific climate hazards (e.g.

5635.text_preview:
the use 
of cover crops as a response to drought).

5636.text_preview:
Demons-
trations can be used on a few specific plots, allo-
wing the rest of the farmers to observe specific 
adaptation options during various growth stages 
and to learn best practices.

5637.text_preview:
A demo plot is a designated area in which an ad-
aptation option or any other farming practice is ful-
ly implemented.

5638.text_preview:
It demonstrates the ideal imple-
mentation of an adaptation option and its effects 
on the plant, soil and yield.

5639.text_preview:
Demo plots can be 
small, e.g.

5640.text_preview:
just a few trees and their surroundings, 
or they can cover an entire coffee plot or farm.

5641.text_preview:
Demo plots are used as field training centers or for 
exchange visits.

5642.text_preview:
Experience has shown that demo 
plots are highly effective, as they enable farmers to 
see and experience first-hand the positive effects 
of improved practices in their environment.

Section 1 |  The essentials of the c&c approach
67
Step 4
It is important to focus the visit on certain aspects 
and give clear instructions to the group before 
being in the field.

5650.text_preview:
This can be done by providing a 
list of questions for participants to answer during 
the trip (see guiding questions below).

5651.text_preview:
The faci-
litator should encourage participants to explore 
the farm, either through discussions with other 
farmers or through physical observations on the 
farm.

5652.text_preview:
After the field visit, ask participants to share 
their experiences and findings in a group discussi-
on and agree on how they can transfer what they 
have learned into their own farming systems.

5653.text_preview:
Finally, producers should be encouraged to 
replicate any suitable adaptation options they see 
during the exchange visit on a small scale, e.g.

5655.text_preview:
Guiding questions for an exchange visit:
u
u What kind of farming technique was intro-
duced as a climate change adaptation option?

5656.text_preview:
u
u What are the steps of implementation?

5658.text_preview:
u
u What kind of changes did you observe  
(e.g.

5659.text_preview:
changes to the soil, coffee tree,  
or any other changes)?

5660.text_preview:
u
u Is this technique relevant to your area?

5661.text_preview:
u
u Is the technique easy and available to  
farmers in your area? u
u What is missing and would be needed for  
farmers to apply this technique in your area?

5663.text_preview:
Exchange visits 
Another way for farmers and extensionists to ex-
perience successfully implemented adaptation op-
tions is to have them visit research stations, demo 
plots or successful producers an

5664.text_preview:
This way, farmers learn through observation: 
“Learning is based on the adage: if I hear I might 
forget, if I see I might remember, if I discover, I 
own for life.” 17 This type of producer-to-produc

5665.text_preview:
An exchange visit, also known as ‘field visit’, 
requires careful planning and a preliminary visit 
by extension staff.

5666.text_preview:
Selected demo plots or demo 
farms must have adaptation options that have 
been visibly implemented.

5667.text_preview:
Be sure to present 
experiences, observations, positive effects and 
lessons learned to visitors in an understandable

the risk of being affected by climate change, e.g.

if a climate hazard and vulnerability exist, can

Therefore, mulching can sometimes 
be considered as an adaptation option and sometimes simply a good agricultural practice.

points during validation and/or implementation of

5719.text_preview:
M&E in climate change adaptation can be more 
challenging18 than other development or agricul-
tural work for a number of reasons, including the 
following:
u
u Climate change is an ongoing, long-ter

5720.text_preview:
This means there can be significant time lags 
between the implementation of adaptation 
options and their measurable impacts.

5721.text_preview:
For 
example, it might take 10 years to find out 
whether planting trees to shade coffee plants 
is effective in reducing their vulnerability to 
increasing heat.

5722.text_preview:
u
u Uncertainties are inherent in the implementa-
tion of adaptation options.

5723.text_preview:
This may relate to 
understandings of how the climate will change 
in the future (and how this may impact coffee 
production), but also includes social or eco-
nomic uncertainties.

5724.text_preview:
These can make it more 
difficult to understand whether good decisions 
are being made for adaptation options and 
their implementation.

5786.text_preview:
In the c&c pilot project in Brazil, drought was 
identified as a key problem in the triangulation 
process in April 2012.

5787.text_preview:
A detailed cost-benefit 
projection from later in 2012 (see c&c tool-
box) identified seedlings in large polybags as a 
promising adaptation option: seedlings remain in 
the nurseries for an additiona

5788.text_preview:
The price per seed-
ling was higher, but mortality was predicted to be 
lower and initial yields superior.

5789.text_preview:
A nursery was found to produce these seedlings 
and farmers were invited to use them – and en-
couraged to plant them directly alongside normal 
seedlings from small polybags.

5790.text_preview:
This allowed for 
close monitoring of how the plants performed.

5791.text_preview:
After one year, the seedlings were assessed and 
compared to the control group on the same plot.

5792.text_preview:
Mortality had dropped by 20% and all other 
indicators, from plant height to stem diameter, 
showed a strong positive effect of using large 
saplings.

5793.text_preview:
Farmers from other groups were invited 
to visit the plot and to observe and discuss the 
effects in the field.

5794.text_preview:
This convinced farmers to try 
out this alternative method as well.

5795.text_preview:
The formal assessment of plant parameters and 
the discussions with farmers formed the foun-
dation for a case study.

Identify your evaluation questions
Having defined the purpose of your M&E process, 
it is now time to consider the evaluation questions 
that will help fulfil this purpose.

5865.text_preview:
A good starting 
point for creating questions is to consider the logic 
behind your adaptation measures and the assump-
tions that you made during the planning stage.

5866.text_preview:
If 
you have developed a project pathway (see Step 
3), you will have already mapped out this logic and 
its inherent assumptions.

5867.text_preview:
Evaluation questions 
should test and challenge the logic outlined in 
your project pathway and help you understand 
what has or has not worked well and why.

5868.text_preview:
Table 18 below provides a general example of 
the types of questions you may need to consi-
der.

5869.text_preview:
These need to be tailored to your particular 
context and adaptation options.

5870.text_preview:
The number of 
questions you select will depend on the comple-
xity of your adaptation process, the resources 
you have available and the purpose of your M&E.

5871.text_preview:
It is best to identify three or four critical evalua-
tion questions, which might also have further 
sub-questions.

5872.text_preview:
Some of the most valuable lessons can be learned 
by looking beyond what you expected to happen 
and exploring what was not anticipated.

training directly led to the sharing of labor at 
key times during the year) or negative (e.g.

5875.text_preview:
the 
technical interventions worked well, but uptake 
was poor because we didn’t involve community 
leaders at the start).

5876.text_preview:
Be sure to include some open questions to take 
these factors into account.

5877.text_preview:
For example, rather 
than simply asking, “Did farmers find the training 
useful?” ask “What did the farmers find useful du-
ring the training?” It is important to capture these 
lessons and also to as

5878.text_preview:

the next phase.

Step 5
This step considers the types of evidence that are 
needed, the challenges of gathering evidence and 
how to develop indicators.

5880.text_preview:
Types of evidence
Two types of evidence often mentioned in M&E 
are quantitative (measurable or quantifiable) and 
qualitative (assessing quality).

5881.text_preview:
Both are import-
ant in answering evaluation questions.

5882.text_preview:
Using the 
PRPR Project outlined on page 58 as an example, 
quantitative data on the numbers of farmers 
attending training sessions would be useful, but 
would still need to be supported by qualitati

5883.text_preview:
from interviews) to understand if, and 
how, the farmers actually used this knowledge on 
their farms.

5884.text_preview:
Indicators that are easy to measure 
are attractive, but often need additional qualitati-
ve information to help in understanding the story 
behind the figures.

5885.text_preview:
Common challenges
As time and resources are often in short supply, 
it is good to openly discuss the challenges that 
arise when collecting data.

5994.text_preview:
Climate variability refers to variations 
in the current state of the climate, e.g.

5995.text_preview:
the amount 
of rainfall we receive from year to year.

5996.text_preview:
Examples 
of climate variability also include extended 
droughts, floods, and conditions that result from 
periodic El Niño and La Niña events (ENSO).

5997.text_preview:
While meteorological records show that earth’s 
temperature is increasing, the analysis of rainfall 
patterns is more uncertain and shows no clear 
trends so far.

5998.text_preview:
However, it remains variable from 
season to season.

5999.text_preview:
One economic sector already being affected by 
climate change is also the most dependent on 
environmental stability and natural resources: 
agriculture.

6000.text_preview:
However, many of the problems that 
farmers are facing are not the results of climate 
change and variability alone.

6001.text_preview:
Climate change and 
variability are rather multipliers of risk, interac-
ting with existing and future hazards to produce 
unusual situations that might not have been 
previously experienced.

6002.text_preview:
The Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change 
(IPCC) defines climate change as “any significant  
change in climate, such as temperature or preci-
pitation, lasting for an extended period of time,

6003.text_preview:
Climate change is primarily a result of global war-
ming, a natural phenomenon.

6004.text_preview:
However, human  
activity has resulted in an increasing amount of 
greenhouse gas emissions in our atmosphere, 
which enforce and speed up this occurrence, lea-
ding to noticeable shifts in temperatur

6005.text_preview:
Climate change has become an internationally 
recognized problem and its impacts are noted on 
a global level, throughout many different sectors 
– agriculture being one of them.

6006.text_preview:
The main climate 
changes resulting from global warming are increa-
sing temperature, changes in rainfall patterns, and 
the intensity and frequency of extreme events 
like storms, floods or droughts.

6007.text_preview:
These potentially 
damaging hydro-meteorological events or pheno-
mena are called climate hazards22.

6008.text_preview: 3.1	 What are climate change and climate variability?

6009.text_preview:
Definition: Climate and weather
Climate is often defined as the weather aver-
aged over a long period of time (normally 30 
years).

6010.text_preview:
Weather describes atmospheric conditions at 
a particular place in terms of air temperature, 
pressure, humidity, wind speed, cloudiness 
and precipitation.

6012.text_preview:

6014.text_preview:

6015.text_preview:
All in all, long-term climate change is expected  
to lead to more frequent, more extreme or more  
unpredictable occurrences of climate hazards.

This may include the timing, frequency and

and cyclones.

The earth receives energy from the sun in form

Solar radiation passes

(GHGs) block some outgoing long-wave infrared 
The importance of the greenhouse effect
The greenhouse effect is a natural phenomenon 
that makes life on our planet possible.

6022.text_preview:
The term is 
used in reference to the world and its atmosphere 
heating up, similar to how a big greenhouse would 
warm up from the sun.

6023.text_preview:
The dominant natural 
greenhouse gases are H20 (water), CO2 (carbon 
dioxide), CH4 (methane), and N20 (nitrous oxide).

If GHG emissions were reduced in line with low

Objective: To help the organization better un-
derstand which natural and human-made events 
have influenced their lives and their surroundings.

6265.text_preview: Materials: Paper (pin board size) and markers.

6267.text_preview:
Procedure
u
u Explain the objective of the timeline.

6268.text_preview:
Ask par-
ticipants to identify events that have influen-
ced individual activities and the activities of 
the organization.

6269.text_preview:
Start with someone iden-
tifying an important event in the past and try 
to determine the year that it happened.

6270.text_preview:
It does 
not have to be the earliest activity remem-
bered.

6271.text_preview:
Record the year and event, and then 
ask for another event. Record the next event, 
as well as the years above and below the 
first.

6272.text_preview:
Help the group work back to the earliest 
events they can remember.

6273.text_preview:
A timeline is a chronological list of key events 
in the history of the organization and its area.

6274.text_preview:
It 
facilitates discussion and examination of past 
trends, actions, problems and achievements.

6275.text_preview:
It is useful to think back on these past events 
and experiences during resource planning 
and decision-making, and to look at how they 
influence present attitudes and actions.

6276.text_preview:
Events on the timeline may include spiritual and 
cultural events, movements of people, introduc-
tions of new technology, natural disasters, poli-
tical events or decisions, development projects 
and

6277.text_preview:
In developing a timeline, participants make a 
record of events from as many generations back 
as they can recall.

6278.text_preview:
Group discussions about the 
timeline provide a good opportunity to ask elders 
about previous happenings and traditional res-
ponses.

Step 2
Seasonal calendar
A seasonal calendar is a tool for documenting 
regular cyclical periods (e.g.

6291.text_preview:
seasonal) and signi-
ficant events that influence the organization.

6292.text_preview:
It 
provides a general picture of important environ-
mental, cultural and socio-economic periods 
throughout the year.

6293.text_preview:
Seasonal calendars are of particular value, as they 
allow local people to represent their understan-
ding of seasons in congruence with cultivation.

6294.text_preview:
These are often different from ‘official’ seasons 
and the international calendar.

6295.text_preview:
Objective: To develop a seasonal calendar for the 
organization.

6296.text_preview:
Materials: Paper, masking tape or pins, pencils, 
pens and colored pens or markers.

6297.text_preview: Required time: One to two hours.

6298.text_preview:
Procedure
u
u Form four groups and make sure to mix young 
and old, as well as male and female participants.

6299.text_preview:
u
u Draw a circle on four sheets of paper and mark 
the highest point of the circle as “beginning 
of the year/January”. Explain that the lowest 
point of the circle represents the middle 
of the yea

6300.text_preview:
Divide the circle into 
12 sections, one for every month.

6301.text_preview:
Hand out 
one prepared sheet of paper with the format

Required time: Five minutes at the end of day one.

6339.text_preview:
Objective: To determine how the organization 
perceives climate change, how these changes will 
affect their lives and how they would like their 
future to look instead.

6340.text_preview:
Reflection: two-way vision 
Procedure
u
u Before leaving after day one, ask the parti-
cipants to think of the future of their coffee 
production, as well as their homes, families 
and communities.

6341.text_preview:
u
u Have them determine what is most likely to 
happen in the future if everything continues 
as it is at present.

6342.text_preview:
u
u Then have them visualize their ideal future.

6343.text_preview:
u
u Ask them to imagine wandering around their 
coffee farms and have them choose their most 
precious resources.

6344.text_preview:
These should be things 
that they can physically hold in their hands 
(e.g.

6345.text_preview:
water, soil, a specific tree, a coffee cherry, 
etc.).

6346.text_preview:
Have them identify up to three of these 
valuable items.

6347.text_preview:
u
u They should then think of anything that would 
be a danger to the items in the future if ever-
ything continues as it is now.

6348.text_preview:
u
u For day two, ask them to come back to the 
workshop with their three valuable items, as 
well as some challenges or problems that are 
or could become dangerous to them (e.g.

6349.text_preview:
a 
specific pest, lack of water, etc.).

Step 2
Objective: To assist participants in determining 
which values are important to their organization 
as a whole.

6351.text_preview: Materials: Paper, pens, markers and masking tape.

6352.text_preview: Required time: One to two hours.

6353.text_preview:
The values of an organization may be widely 
spread, as values vary from participant to partici-
pant.

6354.text_preview:
It is therefore important to prioritize values 
that the entire group considers to be important.

6355.text_preview:
Priority values
List of problems
It is always important to allow producers to 
identify their own needs and arrive at possible 
solutions by themselves.

6356.text_preview:
Listing problems on a 
sheet (or multiple sheets) of paper is a simple, 
but systematic, way to help participants identify 
and further define the issues that concern their 
organization most.

6357.text_preview:
Objective: To systematize the organization’s prob-
lems and challenges.

6359.text_preview: Required time: Half an hour to an hour.

6360.text_preview:
Procedure
u
u A list of problems can be created in several 
ways.

6361.text_preview:
It might include items generated from 
many sources, including meetings, brain-
storms, individual discussions, small group 
exercises, transects or theatre sessions.

6362.text_preview:
The 
list should be kept at the organization and 
continually revised to include more informati-
on throughout the process.

6363.text_preview:
u
u Based on the discussion during day one, have 
participants name the problems they identi-
fied that threaten their most valuable items.

6364.text_preview:
u
u Record all problems or challenges mentioned.

6365.text_preview:
u
u As a group, ask them to prioritize the top three 
or four problems from the list.

6366.text_preview:
u
u Mark the chosen problems and valuable items 
in red and hang the list up where everyone can 
see it.

6367.text_preview: Try to be as specific as possible.

6368.text_preview:
Procedure
u
u Ask participants to recall the three valuable 
items they originally thought of at the end of 
day one.

6369.text_preview:
u
u In pairs, ask them to share their three choices 
and their reasons for choosing each item.

6370.text_preview:
They 
should discuss their choices and, as a pair, 
narrow down their selection to the three most 
important items between them.

6371.text_preview:
u
u When all pairs have finished, combine them into 
groups of four.

6372.text_preview:
Ask each group to repeat the 
activity, with each pair explaining their choices 
and, as a group, choosing a new top three.

6373.text_preview:
u
u Combine the groups of four into eight and 
repeat the activity.

6374.text_preview:
Then form groups of 16, 
and so on, until there is only one group.

6375.text_preview:
u
u Finally, ask the entire group to present their 
three shared values and the reasons for their 
selection.

6376.text_preview:
Review the items that have now 
become less important.

6377.text_preview:
Ask questions such 
as, “How did you decide on this?”, “Were there 
any major disagreements?”, and “What did 
you do when there were disagreements in the 
organization over valuable items?”

Section 2

6378.text_preview:
Let 
the participants brainstorm possible causes of 
the problem by asking, “Why?” Draw a root for 
each cause and write the cause on the root.

6379.text_preview:
u
u Repeat the question, “Why?” for each cause 
mentioned in order to identify secondary 
causes.

6380.text_preview:
Write these lower down on the roots, 
below the primary causes that were identified.

6381.text_preview:
Allow participants to continue until they can-
not come up with any more causes.

6382.text_preview:
u
u Ask them to identify effects or impacts of the 
problem by asking, “What happened?” Draw 
a branch for each effect and write the effect 
directly on the branch.

6383.text_preview:
u
u For each effect, repeat the question, “What 
happened?” which will reveal secondary 
effects.

6384.text_preview:
Place these higher up in the branches, 
above the primary effects.

6385.text_preview:
Allow participants 
to continue until they cannot identify any 
more effects.

problems were identified as very pressing 
earlier) one problem from the prioritized list 
and ask them to

the problem it is suffering from. Point out that 
trees often become sick due to problems in 
the roots, from which it feeds.

In terms of specific climatic events, storms, ir-
regular rain and high temperatures turned out 
to be the most important

and high winds were also identified as having 
a high impact on production.

6486.text_preview:

was rated as the most concerning, with all re-
spondents rating it as high or very high.

6487.text_preview:
When 
asked to rate the seriousness of pests and di-
seases, rust caused the most concern, followed 
by leaf spot (Ojo de Gallo, Mycena citricolor) 
and Cercospora coffeicola.

be identified as a medium to high concern was 
Coffee Berry Borer (CBB).

6569.text_preview:
Finding adaptation options
c&c toolbox  identified generic adaptation  
options (see “tools” in the c&c toolbox).

6570.text_preview:
The word 
‘generic’ is used because, although they may 
work in some circumstances, these tools are not 
universally applicable and will most likely need 
modification to suit local conditions.

6571.text_preview:
They must 
also be adapted to suit the coffee system, rather 
than adapting the coffee system to suit the tools.

6572.text_preview:
u
u Example: Increasing shade may protect against 
high temperatures, but in humid conditions, it 
may increase the likelihood of a disease such as 
American Leaf Spot.

6573.text_preview:
Locally sourced adaptation options: Farmers 
have always been innovative.

6574.text_preview:
Throughout the his-
tory of agriculture, they have been the main sour-
ce of ideas and experimentation.

6575.text_preview:
Therefore, it is 
likely that some farmers in a particular area have 
developed new tools or methods or new variants 
of existing tools that have great potential.

6576.text_preview:
u
u Example: In Brazil, c&c have been testing a  
Brachiaria grass as mulch with Gypsum soil  
treatments, both developed locally by farmers.

6577.text_preview:
Therefore, it is helpful to look at what farmers 
have already been doing to adapt to climate 
change, and concentrate searches more on lower 
altitude coffee, which is most likely to have been 
alrea

6578.text_preview:
Training of field staff may be necessary in order 
for them to look objectively at the adaptation 
efforts of farmers.

6579.text_preview:
Orientation can ensure that 
they record new methods, photograph them and 
fix their locality with Global Positioning System 
(GPS).

6580.text_preview:
u
u Example: Shade trees can provide a range of 
benefits for coffee, but there are downsides.

6581.text_preview:
Ideally, large and multi-year trials of a range of 
tree species should be tested for their utility 
under local conditions, but this would take many 
years to perform.

6582.text_preview:
Instead, seek to find field ex-
amples of coffee performing well under shade in 
extreme conditions and study them as proxies for 
long-term experimentation.

6708.text_preview:
Farmer Field School
A Farmer Field School (FFS) involves a group of 
farmers who evaluate the results, costs and bene-
fits of alternative technologies by experimenting 
in the field.

6709.text_preview:
It is a participatory approach to exten-
sion, whereby farmers use their own discoveries 
to make choices about methods of production.

6710.text_preview:
Objectives
u
u To build the knowledge of farmers through 
hands-on learning about agro-ecosystems and 
ecological principles, such as soil and water 
relationships, fertility and nutrition, orga-
nic

6711.text_preview:
The 
emphasis should be on growing coffee with 
the least disruption to agro-ecosystems.

6712.text_preview:
u
u To help farmers learn about the costs and 
benefits of alternative technologies for 
sustaining and enhancing farm productivi-
ty through adapting to climate change and 
variability.

6713.text_preview:
u
u To train farmers in the cyclical process of  
action, observation, analysis and decision- 
making (agro-ecosystems analysis methodo-
logy, AESA).

6714.text_preview:
This teaches them how to identify 
problems through observation, to analyze the-
se problems by identifying their causes and, 
when these skills are in place, to make their 
own decisions for better c

6715.text_preview:
u
u To increase the ability of farmers to make 
informed decisions about what works best 
for them – based on their own observations 
in the field – and to explain their reasoning.

6716.text_preview:
Recommendations must be tailored to local 
conditions and require local expertise and 
involvement, which only farmers can provide.

6717.text_preview:
u
u To enhance the capacity of extension staff, 
who work in collaboration with researchers 
and serve as facilitators of experiential lear-
ning for farmers.

6718.text_preview:
They facilitate learning rather 
than prescribing a blanket recommendation 
that covers a wide geographic area, but may 
not be relevant.

6719.text_preview:
u
u To train extensionists and researchers on how 
to work with farmers on testing, assessing 
and adapting a variety of options within their 
specific local conditions.

6720.text_preview:
u
u To deliver training based on learning by doing, 
discovery, comparison and non-hierarchical 
relationships between learners and trainers, 
carried out almost entirely in the field.

6721.text_preview:
u
u To abide by the following three major principles:  
--
Grow a healthy crop
--
Observe fields regularly
--
Conserve natural enemies of crop pests
u
u Have farmers understand ecology and climate

6743.text_preview:
FFS extensionist approach
u
u A group of 25-30 farmers affected by and 
interested in solving a coffee production pro-
blem related to climate change and/or climate 
vulnerability form an FFS.

6744.text_preview:
u
u In cooperation with extensionists, farmers de-
sign field experiments (test plots) to compare 
options with their current set-up (plots).

6745.text_preview:
u
u Farmers select a host farmer and a site.

6746.text_preview:
u
u Farmers meet at agreed periods of time 
determined by need, e.g.

6747.text_preview:
crop age and growth 
stages (8-12 meetings per season).

6748.text_preview:
u
u In sub groups, farmers observe and analy-
ze the relationship between a crop and its 
environment.

6749.text_preview:
u
u They measure and record parameters that 
would bring about differences in the perfor-
mance of treatments.

6750.text_preview:
u
u In their subgroups, farmers analyze the data, 
recording differences in performances and the 
reasons for these differences.

6751.text_preview:
Ideally sessions have a fixed frequency, and in a 
coffee FFS, a session takes place every 15 days.

6752.text_preview:
In Brazil, where farmers do not have much time, 
the frequency was one session per month.

6753.text_preview:
A session has usually five routine activities:
u
u Field observation
u
u Analysis of agro-ecosystem
u
u Presentation and discussion
u
u Group dynamics
u
u Special topic
Learning from experience
Farmer

6754.text_preview:
Group dynamics can be used to facilitate the 
understanding of a topic through a game.

6755.text_preview:
For 
example, transporting water from one container 
to another with different materials in order to 
understand the efficiency of the transport of 
water for irrigation.

Step 4
Farmers make management decisions that are 
based on their observations and analyses.

6757.text_preview:
An im-
portant part of the FFS is helping and encouraging 
farmers to conduct their own experiments and 
test out diverse crop management methods.

6758.text_preview:
There are no standard recommendations or packa-
ges of technology, but rather farmers collectively 
decide which methods or aspects of crop manage-
ment should be studied, and take action based 
on th

6759.text_preview:
Through hands-on learning, 
farmers become active learners and independent 
decision-makers.

zing different technologies throughout the 
lifecycle of a specific crop, in this case coff

6761.text_preview:

6762.text_preview:
u
u Optimization of yields and maximization of 
profits achieved within a very short time.

6763.text_preview:
This is due to the collaborative efforts and 
experimentation of farmers, researchers and 
extensionists.

6764.text_preview:
FFS curriculum35
The FFS is based on a tested curriculum, which 
usually covers the entire crop cycle.

6765.text_preview:
The field 
guides, study fields and a collection of group dy-
namic exercises provide the basis for the curricu-
lum, which includes all activities for the learning 
period.

6766.text_preview:
Training in the FFS is experiential and disco-
very-based.

6767.text_preview:
Activities are designed to have par-
ticipants learn by doing and most of the training 
time is spent in the field.

6768.text_preview:
Sharing observations, 
brainstorming and long discussions facilitate 
the exchange of information and generation of 
knowledge.

6769.text_preview:
A cornerstone of the FFS methodology is the 
agro-ecosystem analysis (AESA), which allows far-
mers to observe how a crop interacts with other 
biotic and abiotic factors that co-exist in the field.

6770.text_preview:
This involves regular observations of the crop (for 
coffee, usually every 15 days or once a month).

6771.text_preview:
Participants work in smaller groups of four or five, 
and learn how to make and record detailed obser-
vations including:
u
u Growth stage of the crop
u
u Insects, pests and beneficial numbers

Tips 36
u
u Validation of new adaptation options on a local 
context must be a collaborative effort.

6780.text_preview:
Working 
directly with farmers to test tools is the quickest 
way to identify if there are suitable adaptati-
on practices for local conditions, as well as to 
reveal problems (e.g.

6781.text_preview:
tools could be costly, cum-
bersome, time-consuming or simply ineffective).

6782.text_preview:
u
u Advantages of farm trials: You can quickly get 
feedback from farmers about the trials, their 
acceptability and usefulness.

6783.text_preview:
You can test 
tools over a much wider range of conditions 
than with only one or two field stations.

6784.text_preview:
u
u Disadvantages: You have less control over what 
happens, as farmers might give up too soon, 
or not conduct the trial in the way that was 
agreed upon.

6785.text_preview:
u
u If facilities are available, properly controlled 
farm trials are also important, especially for 
testing new ideas or variants of tools that 
might be expensive or too risky to try directly

7056.text_preview:
Summarizing key messages about which  
activities are most effective
It is helpful to use a ranking exercise that assesses 
how different participants viewed each activity in 
the adaptation process.

7057.text_preview:
There are many ways to 
conduct ranking exercises.

7058.text_preview:
A simple approach is to 
give participants four stones (or a different small 
object,  such as a piece of candy) and ask them 
to place them on a table marked out on a large 
piece of paper.

7059.text_preview:
For example, if you were compa-
ring three activities, Table 45 could be used.

7060.text_preview:
If a participant thought the activity was extremely 
efficient, reasonably affordable, and suitable for 
the farmers, but that the timing was terrible, their 
stones might look like Table 45 below.

7146.text_preview:
They can be 
used to collect basic information about who parti-
cipated in training or c&c activities and how par-
ticipants felt about the support they were given.

They provide a sense of how confident farmers

If you want 
to get extra data on a particular question, e.g.

7149.text_preview:
if 
there are differences between men and women, 
you could ask men and women to use different 
colored marks.

7150.text_preview:
Important 
Note
There are many useful tools available to use 
in your analysis, but remember that no tool 
has all the answers.

7151.text_preview:
It is important to be really 
clear about why you are using specific tools 
and to constantly question the results.

7152.text_preview:
Check 
back with participants and others for accuracy 
and trustworthiness.

7153.text_preview:
Analysis tools help you 
to ask better and more focused questions and 
discover information that might not other-
wise have revealed itself, but none should be 
applied without reflection on both the

7154.text_preview:
When facilitating participatory tools,  
remember to:
u
u listen
u
u encourage 
u
u ask for explanations
u
u probe
u
u verify
u
u expect the unexpected
u
u don’t dominate

where they were in relation to this question a year

There are two main types of questions you can 
ask on spectrum lines:

each year?”
2.

A question that asks for impressions and attitu-
des, e.g.

: “How likely are you to recommend the 
training you received to other coffee farmers?” or

u
u To identify what next steps would be  
most effective in making progress towards

When to use an H diagram
The H diagram can be adapted to fit a number

as a tool to assist locals in

The H diagram is shaped like a wide letter ‘H’ 
that can be used in numerous settings to rate 
something al

7168.text_preview:
confidence in responding to climate change and

Step 5
How to use force fields
u
u First, decide which issue you will use the force 
field to explore.

7171.text_preview:
For example, “assessing what 
supported and what constrained the implemen-
tation of an adaptation activity plan”. u
u Next, encourage participants to list all the 
forces that supported the implemen

7172.text_preview:
u
u List all the forces that got in the way of imple-
menting the activity plan and add them to the 
other side of the paper.

7173.text_preview:
Each driving or cons-
training force can then be ranked by placing it 
closer to or further from the center of the paper, 
according to the strength of the force.

7174.text_preview:
u
u Encourage participants to explore how you 
might increase the driving factors and decrea-
se the constraining factors.

7175.text_preview:
You can identify 
what next steps you might take to put this into 
practice.

7176.text_preview:
For example, in the illustration below, 
one of the things that slows down progress is 
listed as “the information about how a climate 
is changing seems uncertain”.

7177.text_preview:
As it is unlikely 
that you can increase the uncertainty of the 
information, you could discuss how you might 
make a decision despite this uncertainty, e.g.

7178.text_preview:
by 
exploring ‘no-regret’ decisions, which are still 
useful in a range of different future climates.

7179.text_preview:
Force fields 40
40	  Force fields are among the tools described in this report on participatory M&E: www.ifad.org/pub/map/pm_iv.pdf
Objective
To understand the factors that influence a particu-
lar si

7180.text_preview:
These forces can be very dynamic, varying both 
over time and with the experience and aware-
ness of those tasked with identifying them.

7181.text_preview:
They 
can include aspects such as motivations, values, 
needs, personalities, goals, anxieties and ideals, 
as well as more structural aspects of organizatio-
nal decision-making.

7182.text_preview:
When to use force fields
Force fields can be used in all stages of project 
design and planning.

7183.text_preview:
It can also be used to ana-
lyze why an adaptation process has evolved as it 
has and plan how the project might change in the 
future.

7184.text_preview:
Force fields help you to understand what 
positive factors have contributed to progress and 
also what obstacles have been overcome.

u
u To represent ho

7194.text_preview:
u
u To share what participants see as important, 
why they may be feeling stuck and where they 
might start looking for ways to improve the 
situation.

7195.text_preview:
When to use rich pictures
u
u Rich pictures can be used in the evaluation 
stage to share perspectives on the purpose of 
evaluating an adaptation process.

7196.text_preview:
u
u Depending on the question asked, rich pic-
tures can also be used to compare different 
experiences of the same process and the rea-
sons for these differing experiences, or how 
different partic

7197.text_preview:
Participants often worry about the standard of their 
drawing skills, but often end up producing pictures 
that demonstrate their thoughts and concerns far 
more concisely than straightforward answers

7198.text_preview:
Below are some examples of rich pictu-
res illustrating how a group of participants percei-
ved an adaptation process they were part of.

7199.text_preview:
How to use rich pictures
u
u Begin with large sheets of paper and lots of 
colored pens and ask participants to simply 
draw what they see happening in a specific si-
tuation, or in response to a par

7200.text_preview:
They should use pictures to represent the 
situation in a way that can be communicated 
to other people.

7201.text_preview:
This should take between 10 
and 15 minutes.

7202.text_preview:
u
u Give them instructions, such as the following:
--
“Draw a picture that explains your experience 
of participating in this process.”
--
“Draw a picture that explains how you are 
currently feelin

7203.text_preview:
Sharing different rich pictures of how 
people see the adaptation process allows you 
to identify connections, differences, opportuni-
ties and contradictions that might have been 
missed in straightf

7204.text_preview:
It allows 
participants to question their assumptions 
about what is happening, which may result in 
rethinking how they understand the situation 
and thus influence what is to be evaluated.

7205.text_preview:
A 
facilitator can serve to identify where common 
themes and different ideas emerge.

Step 5
How to use conversation mapping
u
u Write the trigger issue in the center of a large 
piece of paper with a

7207.text_preview:
u
u Ask one participant to respond to this trigger 
to start a conversation which is then recorded 
on the paper and linked to the central trigger.

7208.text_preview:
u
u Have the others respond to this or the central 
trigger and also record their contributions so 
that the map branches out.

7209.text_preview:
There should be no 
attempt to shape this process as this is a tool 
for understanding the whole range of perspec-
tives with no attempt to collect or analyze 
them at this stage.

7210.text_preview:
u
u If the map becomes too large for the paper, 
tape on new paper.

7211.text_preview:
It is normal for the map to 
become very messy and full of information.

7212.text_preview:
u
u When people have had enough (or time runs 
out), it is time to reflect on the map (and the 
process of making it).

7213.text_preview:
Ask participants what 
the map shows and about their perceptions or 
understandings of the trigger.

7214.text_preview:
Draw out key the-
mes and anything that has changed in people’s 
perspectives as a result of creating the map.

7215.text_preview:
Conversation mapping 43 
Objective
Conversation maps present different understan-
dings and insights of a situation that emerge from 
a conversation.

When to use conversation mapping
This tool can be used to capture different obser-
vations, feelings and general reactions to a ‘trig-
ger’ issue.

The trigger issue is normally phrased 
as a question, e.g.

“What was your experience of

change adaptation options?” Or,  “What did you 
most value from your participation in the imple-
mentation of climate chan

Helped me to think about 
the bigger system and how 
this influ

They can be used in an

ween key stakeholders were thought to be at the

with how they were at the e

They also demons-
trate how relationships change and why.

Ranking exercises
Many different types of participatory ranking

larly in the data gathering and analysis stages – to

The approaches are not

for those who would like to conduct an evaluati-
on process that investigate

For more information 
about each of the approaches, please follow the

7228.text_preview:
Participatory theatre
Participatory theatre is a multi-stakeholder dialo-
gue that uses theatre as an informal, creative but 
serious way of exploring different perspectives and 
responses along the c

7229.text_preview:
It allows 
different actors to exchange information, formulate 
and prioritize issues and identify collective solu-
tions through short story writing and performance.

7230.text_preview: It does not involve a formal play or production.

7231.text_preview:
The term ‘theatre’ simply refers to participants 
as being both ‘actors’, who narrate, write and 
act short stories, and as being an ‘active audi-
ence’ that watches short plays.

7232.text_preview:
The idea is that, 
following each short story, a dialogue is held 
between the actors and the audience, in contrast 
Additional visual and narrative approaches
to traditional theatre in which the acto

7233.text_preview:
The role of the audience 
is to help each group of participants to refine the 
problem and the solutions presented.

7234.text_preview:
This approach has been used extensively across 
the world (it is sometimes called ‘theatre for 
development’) and has been especially successful 
with the coffee sector in Uganda.

7235.text_preview:
Participatory video 45 
A participatory video is a tool that can be used by 
participants to tell the story of what has changed 
as a result of implementing adaptation to climate 
change in their area

7236.text_preview:
The finished film can be 
used to present their ideas directly to funders 
and decision-makers outside of their local area.

7237.text_preview:
Thus, their learning can be shared more widely 
to influence decision-making processes beyond 
their local context.

7238.text_preview:
Participatory photo stories 46
Photo stories can be used in a similar way to ex-
plain how livelihoods, vulnerabilities and oppor-
tunities have changed throughout the adaptation 
process, and what ha

Step 5
47	 betterevaluation.org/plan/approach/outcome_mapping

7241.text_preview: This is quite a simple tool.

7242.text_preview:
You simply lend each 
participant or group of participants a camera 
and ask them to take pictures of things they feel 
represent something about their experience in 
the adaptation process.

7243.text_preview:
This can include what has 
worked well and what has not, and any surprising 
things that were perhaps unexpected.

7244.text_preview: You can also be more specific with instructions.

7246.text_preview:
ask participants to take 10 photos of things 
they think went well, and 10 photos of things that 
represent whatever needs further improvement.

7247.text_preview:
When cameras are returned and photos printed, 
you can use these to compare and contrast, and to 
stimulate discussion.

7248.text_preview:
Look for overlaps of where 
people photographed the same things.

7249.text_preview:
Outcome mapping 47
Outcome mapping was developed by the In-
ternational Development Research Centre in 
Canada (IDRC) as a way of planning, monitoring 
and evaluating with a focus on what contributes

7250.text_preview:
Outcome mapping has a lot to offer in the evalua-
tion of adaptation options, as it accepts that 
adaptation processes are complex and dynamic; 
it recognizes that there may be unexpected and 
uninten

7251.text_preview:
It 
also acknowledges that outcomes arise as the 
result of a number of factors rather than a single 
action.

7252.text_preview:
Outcome mapping provides a way to draw 
together different contributions to an outcome, 
which is essential in order to learn more about 
what supports successful adaptation.

7253.text_preview:
Most significant change 48
This approach is based on listening to what 
people (beneficiaries, participants, stakeholders, 
etc.)

7254.text_preview:
think have been the most significant changes 
resulting from an adaptation process.

7255.text_preview:
It does not 
require any professional skills to facilitate and is 
easy to communicate across cultures, as people 
generally find it easy to tell stories about events 
they think were important.

7256.text_preview:
There is also no need to explain what an indicator 
is and it is a good way to pick up unanticipated 
changes and changes that may challenge as-
sumptions of what is happening.

7257.text_preview:
This approach 
encourages people to engage in the analysis as 
well as data collection stages of an adaptation 
process, as they have to explain why they believe 
one change is more important than ano

7258.text_preview:
It 
can be used to monitor and evaluate bottom-up 
initiatives that do not have predefined outcomes 
against which to evaluate.

7259.text_preview:
Learning history 49
A learning history is described as a ‘jointly told 
tale’ between outsider researchers and insider ac-
tors around a tangible outcome.

7260.text_preview:
It aims at bringing 
together analysis and story in a way that has value 
both for those originally involved in the work and 
others seeking to learn from it.

7261.text_preview:
A learning history account attempts to get into 
the ‘messy’ human aspects of what happened 
during implementation.

7262.text_preview:
It aims to present a 
number of perspectives on a situation rather than 
synthesizing several accounts into one story.

7263.text_preview:
It 
is presented as a multi-voiced and multi-leveled 
account that charts what happened, and provides 
quotes from those involved and reflections from 
researchers during the process and analysis of

7693.text_preview:
Case Study - Crotalaria and Brachiaria  
Case Study Background Data 
Tool category: 
Adaptation on the farm 
 
Details: 
Planting Density:  
3.333 /ha 
Soil Type:  
Loamy soil 
S

7694.text_preview:
farmers: 14 
 Area under coffee:  2.8 ha/farmer 
 
Tested with smallholders 
through Farmer Field 
Schools (FFS) 
 
Results 
1.

7695.text_preview:
Coffee plots with cover crops between coffee rows presented productivity and net income per 
hectare increase.

7696.text_preview:
The coffee productivity with Brachiaria brizantha covering the rows was 27.8 
bags/hectare, with Crotalária spectabilis it was 29.1 bags/hectare, while the productivity with 
weed chemical control was

7697.text_preview:
Compared to coffee that had weed chemical 
control, the coffee with cover crops increased an average of 2.1 bags/hectare.

7698.text_preview:
It was observed 
that the plots with cover crops had a net income of R$7,266/ha, while plots without cover crops 
had R$6,423.

7699.text_preview: This represents a 13.1% increase in average income/hectare.

7701.text_preview:
Other important results were the changes in the soil characteristics that are favorable to the 
crop development, such as the increase in the organic matter content and the moisture 
retention capacit

7702.text_preview:
Pros & Advantages + Learnings 
Cons & Disadvantages + Things to take into account 
 The cover crops favour changes in the soil’s 
characteristics that improve aspects such as 
fertility, organic matt

7704.text_preview:
 Diminishes (eliminates) the use of 
agrochemicals for weed control between 
coffee rows, generally prejudicial for soil and 
farmer’s health.

7705.text_preview:
 Low installation and management cost – 
R$310 for management of Crotalaria 
spectabilis and R$493 for Brachiaria 
brizantha.

7706.text_preview:  The seeds for cover crops are easily obtained.

7707.text_preview:
 Crotalaria spectabilis may reduce 
Meloidogyne genus nematode populations, in 
addition to fixing atmospheric nitrogen in the 
soil.

7708.text_preview:
  Brachiaria ruziziensis is a C4 species, which 
tend to be more drought resistant than C3 
species like coffee.

7709.text_preview:
Besides that, it presents a 
deep root system that promotes the nutrient 
cycling from deeper layers to the soil’s 
surface.

7710.text_preview:
 The cover crops are not appropriate for high 
density coffee crops, because they hinder other 
cultural practices carried out in the coffee.

7711.text_preview:
 There must be a defined plan for managing the 
cover crops, planting it in rainy seasons and 
cutting/incorporating according to the 
phenological cultivation cycle in each locality.

7712.text_preview:
 Crotalaria spectabilis presents a fibrous stem, so 
the cut must be low, to avoid forming “little 
trunks” that can posteriorly cause damage to the 
harvest mats.

7713.text_preview:
 Brachiaria ruziziensis must be correctly 
managed, with two or three cuts during the 
coffee cultivation cycle.

7714.text_preview:
Due to its accelerated 
growth and form of propagating, some farmers 
are resistant to its use.

7715.text_preview:
 Both Crotalaria spectabilis and Brachiaria 
ruziziensis can be managed in mixed covering 
systems by using herbicides before the coffee 
harvesting.

What is the objective of applying the adaptation option and how do we expect the obj

7717.text_preview:
The case’s objective is to diminish the productivity loss risks due to temperature increase, irregular 
rainfall and prolonged drought periods by using cover crops as adaptation practices to climatic

7718.text_preview:
Increase in productivity and net 
income in coffee plots with 
cover crops in comparison to the 
local practices (witness).

7719.text_preview:
 Productivity in bags/ha 
 Net income in R$/ha 
 
Increase in organic matter 
content and the soil’s moisture 
retention capacity in plots with 
cover crops in comparison to the 
local practices.

7721.text_preview:
 Days in soil’s field capacity 
after the last rain.

7722.text_preview:
temperature increase 
 irregular rain 
prolonged drought 
loss of production and quality 
soil erosion 
decrease of yield and income 
physiological changes 
increase of pests and diseases

7723.text_preview:
Also identified was the need to validate adaptation practices 
for soil conservation, such as improving the physical, chemical and biological characteristics, besides 
reducing exposure to extreme cli

7724.text_preview:
The impact of 
these events cause physiological changes in the cultivation, increase in pests and diseases, productivity 
loss, quality loss and income reduction for the farmers.

7725.text_preview:
Description of the expected outcome: The cover crops are grass species, legumes, among other species 
that are planted between the coffee rows.

7726.text_preview:
These crops form a natural coverage, either living or dead 
when cut.

7727.text_preview:
They promote the increase in organic matter content in the soil, provide more nutrients to 
the coffee, increase the water retention, protect against erosion caused by heavy rain and reduce high 
surf

7728.text_preview:
As a result, it is expected to obtain an increase in productivity and 
consequently increasing profit for the farmers.

7729.text_preview: How is the adaptation option applied?

7731.text_preview:
Step 
Picture 
1 
 
A meeting between farmers, 
extensionists and researchers in the 
triangulation process is the first step 
to identify climatic threats, impacts 
and to define adaptation measures.

7732.text_preview:
Further, at that time the validation 
studies are planned, objectives, results 
and indicators identified and actions 
taken to the field.

7733.text_preview:
2 
 
Once the cover species, grass or 
legumes are selected, it is necessary to 
decide the planting time and the 
arrangement between coffee rows.

7734.text_preview:
For example, Brachiaria ruziziensis was 
planted by sowing through throwing 
with a 50 cm spacing from the coffee 
projection.

7735.text_preview:
For the Crotalaria 
spectabilis case, the planting was 
made in furrows spaced in 10 cm in 
the center of the space between the 
coffee rows.

7736.text_preview:
3 
 
The Brachiaria ruziziensis field must be 
cut periodically when the crop reaches 
approximately one-meter high.

7737.text_preview:
Depending on the climate and the 
rains this can happen between 60 and 
90 days.

7738.text_preview:
The grass can be cut with 
manual or mechanic shearer.

7739.text_preview:
The cuttings should be placed near the 
coffee plants base (in the coffee “skirt” 
projection) to increase the water 
retention and provide nutrients as the 
cut leaves decompose.

7740.text_preview:
4 
The Crotalaria spectabilis field will be 
cut in the flowering stage phase when 
there is more biomass quantity to 
incorporate organic matter in the soil 
beyond the biological fixation of 
atmosp

7741.text_preview:
The cut can be done with manual 
shearer or machete as low as possible.

7742.text_preview:
5 
When cut, Briachiaria ruziziensis forms 
a dead and continuous coverage that 
brings benefits to the soil by reducing 
direct impacts, such as extreme 
temperatures and strong erosive rains.

7743.text_preview:
This practice also lowers soil 
temperatures, reduces thermal 
amplitudes and conserves moisture for 
a longer period.

7744.text_preview:
6 
 
Technicians and farmers evaluate the 
results of the cover crops in retaining 
soil’s moisture and temperature.

7745.text_preview:
The 
image also illustrates the difference 
between covered soil (with 
decomposing Crotalaria spectabilis) 
and the soil exposed to the extreme 
climatic conditions.

7746.text_preview:
The moisture in 
the covered soil is higher than the 
exposed soil.

7747.text_preview:
The same is true for 
organic matter content.

7748.text_preview:
7 
 
During the harvest, the farmer 
evaluates the productivity of the plots 
to reach conclusions about the effect 
of the adaptation practices to adapt 
the climatic changes performed in its 
proper

7749.text_preview:
The farmer registers all of 
the production costs and economically 
evaluates the feasibility of the 
practices performed in its property, by 
being able to visualize the productive 
return (bags/ha)

7750.text_preview:
Implementation framework 
The study on the cover crop effect over the soil’s characteristics, the productivity and the income of the 
farmers was performed through a validation plot of Farmer Field Sc

7751.text_preview:
The validation plots had 
a 500m² area for each of the treatments.

7752.text_preview:
Treatments: 
 
Treatment 1 – Brachiaria ruziziensis cover crop between coffee rows with three cutting times.

7753.text_preview:
 
Treatment 2 – Crotalaria spectabilis cover crops between coffee rows and incorporated to the 
soil by the time it reaches 30% flowering.

7754.text_preview:
 
Treatment 3 – no cover crops; conventional weed control with three herbicide applications per 
agricultural year.

7755.text_preview:
Measurement strategy for effectiveness 
Indicator 
a) Productivity in bags/ha 
b) Net Income in R$/ha 
c) Organic matter % 
d) Days in soil field capacity after the last rain 
Definition 
a) Number of

7756.text_preview:
This 
measure is one of the indicators that manifest the efficiency of the 
practices over adverse climatic events.

7757.text_preview:
b) The net income allows to evaluate if the practice has a positive 
economic return compared with the conventional practice.

7758.text_preview: c) The organic matter is one of the main fertility.

7759.text_preview:
Additionally, the 
organic matter is related to the enhanced infiltration and moisture 
retention condition of the soil. Thus, an increase in the organic matter 
content means more fertility, more lif

7760.text_preview:
d) A soil with prolonged period at field capacity after rain guarantees 
water retention capacity and is in condition to provide water and 
nutrients to the crop for longer.

7761.text_preview:
This also reduces the risk that the 
crop evaporates and loses water quickly conducting water to a hydric 
stress state.

7779.text_preview:
Main findings of case study 
The cover crops had a positive impact in terms of studied indicators.

7780.text_preview:
a) Productivity: The coffee treatments with coverage between coffee rows had a higher 
productivity than the treatment without coverage in which weeds were managed by chemical 
method (control).

7781.text_preview:
The control had a productivity of 26.4 bags/ha, the Brachiaria ruziziensis 
portion had a productivity of 27.8 bags/ha and the Crotararia spectabilis had a productivity of 
29.1 bags/ha.

(no coverage), coverage with Brachiaria ruziziensis and coverage with Crotalaria spectabilis between

productivity/ha and a higher net income/ha.

of R$ 6,423; the coffee plot with Brachiaria ruziziensis coverage had a net income of R$ 6,913 
and the coffee plot with Crotalaria spectabilis cover

was 2.2%, and in the covered plots was 2.7% (average of both, Brachiaria and Crotalaria).

other high seed production legumes to continue 
the soil management with coverage.

Affordability

investment, maintenance cost and the availability of inputs?

High 
          X 
Low

        X

7815.text_preview:
Please comment: 
Are there any external costs?

7818.text_preview:
If costs are high because inputs are not available, 
what inputs?

7820.text_preview:
In Brazil there are several cover crop seeds 
providers.

7821.text_preview:
The companies offer certified seeds and 
deliver them wherever the requester wants.

7822.text_preview:
Any other comment: 
It is necessary to test other cover crops species, 
especially the ones that can be multiplied in the 
own community to eliminate the dependency of 
buying seeds.

7823.text_preview:
Effectiveness 
Leading question: Does the tool provide the expected benefits to farmers?

7824.text_preview:
High 
          X 
Low 
          
Don’t Know 
         
High: The objective of the tool has been met for the farmers.

7825.text_preview:
Please, comment: 
What benefits did farmers expect from this tool?

7826.text_preview:
The farmers expected productivity and net income 
increase due to increases in organic matter 
content, fertility, soil’s physics and microbiology.

7827.text_preview:
Characteristics that improve physiological and 
productive conditions, guaranteeing higher 
productivity and aptitude to adapting to climatic 
changes.

7828.text_preview: If the objective has not been met, why?

7830.text_preview:
Have there been any significant external issues 
which influenced the effectiveness (positive or 
negative) of this tool?

7832.text_preview:
The climatic conditions with irregular rainfall and 
drought periods helped to prove the efficiency of 
the cover crops when comparing to regular weed 
management.

7834.text_preview:
The cover crops were effective in controlling 
broad-leaf weeds and bindweed by competing for 
space and sunlight.

7835.text_preview:
Timing  /Urgency 
Leading Question: Is the amount of time that this tool takes to implement (from starting 
implementation until benefits accrue) reasonable to farmers?

7836.text_preview:
High 
          X 
Low 
          
Don’t Know 
         
High: The tool is short/mid-term (taking into account the productive cycle of the coffee, needed inputs, 
preparation and execution time).

7837.text_preview:
Please, comment: 
If implementation takes too long, why?

7840.text_preview:
The production systems with conventional weed 
management can be quickly transformed into 
alive/dead coverage management.

7841.text_preview:
It only takes 
the farmer’s decision and the technical assistance 
to access the technology’s knowledge.

8396.text_preview:
In this
shaded environment, the coﬀee plant has co-evolved with a wide array of pests and
diseases.

8397.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8397.text_preview:
The fungal pathogen Hemileia vastatrix is the most notorious of all known coﬀee
plant diseases.

8398.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8398.text_preview:
With a rich history rooted in colonial trade and power struggles, H.
vastatrix has had its lion’s share of research and scrutiny by the plant pathology
community.

8399.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8399.text_preview:
Though this disease was discovered more than 150 years ago, many
unknowns concerning its spread and persistence across the tropics still exist today.

8400.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8400.text_preview:
Despite its relevance to coﬀee production, there is little global data that synthesizes the
impact of this disease on coﬀee yield and plant health.

8401.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8401.text_preview:
Best practices for control of coﬀee
leaf rust are contentious.

8402.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8402.text_preview:
Genetic resistance has been breaking down in cultivars across
the coﬀee belt over the past decade.

8403.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8403.text_preview:
How can farmers best control outbreaks of the
disease?

8404.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8404.text_preview:
Are these practices at odds with new trends and challenges in coﬀee farming
(e.g.

8405.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

8406.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8406.text_preview:
What are the future prospects of our
global coﬀee supply under pressure from this rampant disease?

8407.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8407.text_preview:
All these questions are
examined in this case study using pertinent literature sources and supplemented by
coﬀee farmers or extension service providers in Latin America and Africa.

the tea plant, the cocoa bean, and the coﬀee bean.” – William Ukers, 1921
The appropriately titled book All about Coﬀee (Ukers, 1922) proposed that the lure and
universal appeal of coﬀee can b

8420.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8420.text_preview:
First, the
enjoyable, aromatic sensations of drinking coﬀee and second, the increased eﬃciency
which provides its recipient via caﬀeine stimulation.

8421.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8421.text_preview:
It is no wonder that coﬀee is virtually
ubiquitous in kitchens, cafes and in the hands of pedestrians on just about every street
corner.

8422.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8422.text_preview:
Ethiopia may be the widely accepted origin of the oldest known species of coﬀee,
Coﬀea arabica, but Yemen is thought to be the birthplace of consuming coﬀee in the
beverage form we know today (Friis,

8423.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8423.text_preview:
Early observations from Ethiopia described
the invigorating eﬀects of chewing roasted coﬀee beans as “better than a loaf of bread or
a meal of meat” (Friis, 2015).

8424.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8424.text_preview:
In Yemen, coﬀee as a hot drink went by at least three Arabic
names: “bunna”, “gahve” and “geschr” and was said to be drunk by people at any time of
day (Friis, 2015).

8425.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8425.text_preview:
Nowadays, most coﬀee drinkers could not imagine going a day without
their cup of “liquid gold”.

8426.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8426.text_preview:
This means that coﬀee is a big business; annual global earnings
exceed US$200 billion.

8427.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8427.text_preview:
Consequently, any pest and disease which impact coﬀee yield are
of keen interest to the farmer and the scientiﬁc community at large.

8428.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

8429.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

8430.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8430.text_preview: Severe leaf defoliation caused by coﬀee leaf rust can lead to plant death.

8431.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8431.text_preview:
Courtesy of Dr
Melanie Bordeaux, director of NICAFRANCE Foundation’s research centre, Nicaragua.

8432.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8432.text_preview: Coﬀee leaf rust (CLR) is one of the most signiﬁcant diseases to strike coﬀee production.

8433.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8433.text_preview:
Due to its widespread prevalence across all global coﬀee-growing regions and the
calamity it brings in terms of yield reduction, CLR is by far the most studied coﬀee
disease.

8434.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8434.text_preview:
CLR damages coﬀee plants by causing heavy leaf defoliation, leading to dramatic
yield losses (up to 75%) and in some cases plant death (Fig.

8435.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

8436.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8436.text_preview:
Countries plagued by CLR
suﬀer ﬁnancial losses at the national level, which have trickle-down eﬀects on poor
farmers and, in extreme circumstances, has led to the mass abandonment of coﬀee
farms.

8437.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8437.text_preview:
In fact, estimates suggest that the most recent epidemic of CLR cost up to US$1
billion in losses and cut 250,000 jobs, mainly on farms.

8438.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8438.text_preview:
CLR was ﬁrst oﬃcially discovered on uncultivated, wild coﬀee oﬀ the shores of Lake
Victoria (Kenya) in 1861 by a British explorer (Koutouleas et al., 2019).

8439.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8439.text_preview:
Yet it was not until
1869 that the disease reached the public eye after it reaped havoc across several colonial
Fig.

8440.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

8441.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8441.text_preview: Tea, coﬀee and chocolate were once considered as luxury imports by the British.

8442.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

8443.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8443.text_preview:
Obtained from the British Museum, Public domain, via
Wikimedia Commons.

card_(BM_Heal,68.45).jpg

1869 that the disease reached the public eye after it reaped havoc across several colonial
coﬀee plantations in Sri Lank

8445.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8445.text_preview:
The British colonialists were so taken
aback by CLR in their ﬁelds that they resorted to tearing out the coﬀee plants and
replacing them with tea bushes instead.

8446.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8446.text_preview:
Through this case study, the longstanding history of CLR will be considered and linked to
key colonial trade activities (Fig.

8447.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

8448.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8448.text_preview:
The relevance of the disease will be highlighted brieﬂy
in terms of modern coﬀee farming practices using testimonies and data from Central
American and East African coﬀee farms.

8449.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8449.text_preview:
Future prospects of coﬀee farming in new ways
to combat disease pressure by H. vastatrix will also be explored.

8450.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8450.text_preview:
Causal Agent: Hemileia vastatrix
Hemileia vastatrix
Hemileia vastatrix Berk.

8451.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8451.text_preview:
& Broome is an obligate parasitic fungus in family Pucciniaceae
(Koutouleas et al., 2019).

8452.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8452.text_preview:
This means that the fungus cannot survive in the absence of its
plant host.

8453.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8453.text_preview:
Optimal environmental conditions for the development of H. vastatrix are 21–
25°C air temperature with 100% relative humidity.

8454.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8454.text_preview:
CLR infection peaks, therefore, tend to
occur immediately after the peak of the rainy season across tropical and sub-tropical
regions.

8455.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8455.text_preview:
Under optimal environmental conditions, a fungal germ tube of H. vastatrix
penetrates via stomatal openings on the underside of the coﬀee leaf.

8456.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8456.text_preview:
Upon entry, H.
vastatrix grows nutrient-absorbing mycelium within the leaf mesophyll cells using
haustoria to invaginate the mesophyll cells to obtain nutrients.

8457.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
8457.text_preview:
Vibrant bouquet-shaped,
orange uredinia and telia sporulate from the stomata (Figs 3 and 4).

8458.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

8459.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

8460.text_preview: Uredinium of H. vastatrix budding orange rust-coloured urediniopores (bar = 20 μm).

8461.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf

8462.filename: Coffee Leaf Rust_ Wreaking Havoc in Coffee Produc….pdf
